events.title: Button Book Club
events.description: Do you love to read but hate deadlines? Or are you just too busy to attend traditional book club meetings? If so, our Button Book Club is perfect for you! Each month there will be a new book to read and a brand new pin to collect! How It Works Pick Your Book! Each month will feature a new Easy/Picture, Beginning Reader, Middle Grade, and Teen book. Simply pick which level you want to read and check out the book! Share Your Thoughts! Come back anytime during the month and write/draw your favorite part of the book. Get Your Pin! Each book will have it's own special, collectible pin. Participate every month to collect them all! Plus, get a free lanyard with your first pin to show them off! December Books: Easy/Picture: Pop! Goes the Nursery Rhyme by Betsy Bird Beginning Readers: First Flight by SJ King Middle Grade: The Library of Unruly Treasures by Jeanne Birdsall Teen: His Face is the Sun by Michelle Jabes Corpora

events.title: Manga of the Month Club
events.description: Do you love manga, but hate in-person book discussions? Try our Manga of the Month Club!Pick up the first volume of the month's chosen series along with a review sheet. Return a completed review sheet to the Westwood Branch at any time and receive a small prize.This activity is recommended for ages 13-18 since the series are typically rated T for Teen.

events.title: Winter Scavenger Hunt
events.description: This is a fun variation on the Adult Winter Checkout Challenge so that kids can get involved, too! Get a bookmark with prompts from the circulation desk then find books that match! Bring the completed bookmark to the front desk for a prize.

events.title: Teen Passive Book Club: Mysteries
events.description: This month's teen passive book club theme is mysteries! Our featured title for February is Under the Same Stars by Libba Bray: Three timelines converge to unveil the mysterious disappearance of two girls during WWII. Grab a copy (or any alternate title) in the teen area & an activity packet!

events.title: Button Book Club
events.description: Button Book Club is a passive book club, where participants read a book inspired by the monthly theme, fill in a brief worksheet and collect button. In February the topic is Works: Business, Labor and Innovation. With a curated selection of books on everything from play-doh, the Wright Brothers, and beer making in Cincinnati there is something for everyone. Something else spark your interest? We can't wait to hear what it is.Please see staff if you have any questions.

book.title: Club is a passive book club, where participants read a book inspired

events.title: StoryWalk® with Dougherty Station and San Ramon Libraries
events.description: Get some exercise and read the latest story installed at the StoryWalk in Central Park. The winter themed story is called Except Antarctica, written and illustrated by Todd Sturgell. Follow turtle and learn about animals found on every continent except Antarctica!The San Ramon StoryWalk® is a permanent feature in San Ramon’s Central Park. The 20-station project features a new book four times a year. The San Ramon StoryWalk® project is a partnership with the Rotary Club of San Ramon, the City of San Ramon, the San Ramon Library Foundation, and the Library. The Central Park StoryWalk® begins near the Alcosta parking lot to the right of the playground, ending at the Community Center’s rear fountain. The StoryWalk Project was created by Anne Ferguson of Montpelier, VT and developed in collaboration with the Kellogg-Hubbard Library. StoryWalk is a registered service mark owned by Ms. Ferguson.

location.name: San Ramon Community Center at Central Park

events.title: Teen Passive Book Club: Contemporary
events.description: This month's teen passive book club theme is contemporary! Our featured title is We Are Okay by Nina LaCour: After leaving California to go to college in New York, Marin must face the truth about what happened in the final weeks of summer when her friend comes to visit. Grab a copy (or any alternate title) in the teen area & an activity packet!

events.title: Theatre Club
events.description: Lights up on a brand-new scene! Read from our selected plays in preparation or join us to read aloud day of! Take a chance to familiarize yourself with some of the most popular, famous works from the stage – both in writing and performance.

events.title: (Virtual) Club de Lectura en Español:  La Negra Angustias / Francisco Rojas Gonzalez
events.description: Únase al club de lectura en Español este mes por una discusion de La Negra Angustias por Francisco Rojas Gonzalez. Un programa de Illinois Humanities, el Club de Lectura en Español Enhorabuena se junta mensualmente para discutir libros en Español. Este grupo esta abierto a cualquier adulto interesade en lectura y en discutir lectura con otros adultos. Este programa esta planeado para ser en persona. Mande correo para registrarse para obtener detalles por cualquier cambio. Accesibilidad ¿Necesita interpretación de lenguaje de señas u otra asistencia de accesibilidad para este evento? Por favor llame al (312) 747-8184 o envíe un correo electrónico a access@chipublib.org para solicitar alojamiento. Las solicitudes deben hacerse al menos 14 días hábiles antes del evento.

events.title: Tutoring Club
events.description: Boost reading and math skills with our KU tutor. Register for an in-person session here. Tutoring in Reading: Pre-K–6th gradeTutoring in Math: K–9th grade This session will meet in the Children's Study Nooks. Check in at the Children's desk upon arrival. Please do not sign up for more than one session a day or two sessions a week. Sessions may be booked up to 2 weeks in advance.

events.description: The conversation group is a drop in group where anyone is welcome to come and practice conversations in English, in a friendly and relaxed environment. This is not a class, but an opportunity to talk with others in English and to meet new people in the community. Especially good for ESOL learners. Free and no bookings are needed.

events.title: Online Book Club: The Last Thing He Told Me
events.description: Join Erin for a blog conversation with a new book each month. This month: The Last Thing He Told Me. --- Don't want to commit to a definite book club date and time? No worries! Read at your own pace and join Erin's weekly blog conversation about a different book each month. March's selection is The Last Thing He Told Me by Laura Dave.

events.title: Spice of the Season
events.description: Do you love to cook and want to try new flavors and recipes? It’s time to get spicy and join the Spice of the Season Club! Each season we will feature a new spice and make it available in a take-home kit. Spice kits will be available the first Monday of the quarter (Jan, April, July and Oct). The kits will include a small sample of the spice, a brochure with the history of the spice, recipes from the JCPL collection, book recommendations and more. Additional recipes will be provided for each seasonal spice in the months between each spice drop. Spice kits will be available on the first Monday of each quarter, with a limited number available. ¿Le encanta cocinar y quisiera probar nuevos sabores y recetas? Únase a nuestro club de especie de la temporada. Cada temporada tendremos una especie disponible para llevar a casa en un kit preparado. Los kits de especie serán disponible el primer lunes de cada temporada (enero, abril, julio y octubre.) Los kits incluyen una muestra de la especie, un folleto con información histórica de la especie, recetas, recomendaciones, y más. Tendremos recetas adicionales para recoger en los meses entre el cambio de especie. Los kits de especie serán disponibles el primer lunes de cada temporada. Cantidades de kits disponibles serán limitadas.

events.title: Bullfrog Morning Book Club
events.description: The Bullfrog Morning Book Club meets once a month at the Bullfrog Mall Branch. For adults. Please register. To obtain your copy of the book of the month, visit the Bullfrog Mall Branch.. Copies of the title for the following month will be handed out at the meeting to those who are registered for the next meeting. Remaining books will be set aside on a first-come, first-served basis for the rest of the registered participants. The due date for all book club selections is the next month's meeting date. By participating in this program, you acknowledge that you accept and agree to Guelph Public Library's Code of Conduct..Accessible programs and events Sensory kits are available by request at all library programs. Please let us know a few days before a program if you need any accessibility accommodations so we can plan for you. For sign language interpreters we ask for a minimum of two weeks’ notice. Alternative formats are available as per the Accessibility per Ontarians Act by contacting Library Communications at 519-824-6220.

events.title: Monday Morning Book Club
events.description: The Monday Morning Book Club meets from September to June at the Main Library in the New Books section on the Main Floor at 10:00 a.m. Please contact book club host, Amy Lychwa, for details. Please note that we have a limited number of books available. As such, copies will be made available to attending members after the meeting and are given on a first-come, first-served basis for registered members. Any remaining books will be set aside at the Main Library Circulation desk and will be available to check out. The due date for all book club selections is the next month's meeting date. The timely return of books ensures that book clubs can run smoothly and is an important part of the process. By participating in this program, you acknowledge that you accept and agree to the Guelph Public Library Code of Conduct.Alternative formats are available as per the Accessibility per Ontarians Act by contacting Library Communications at 519-824-6220.Accessible programs and events Sensory kits are available by request at all library programs. Please let us know a few days before a program if you need any accessibility accommodations so we can plan for you. For sign language interpreters we ask for a minimum of two weeks’ notice. When registering for a program with a support person, please include them as an additional guest.

events.title: Community Meeting: #1 Book Club
events.description: Community meeting. This is not a library-sponsored event. Date and time may change without notice.

events.title: High Intermediate ESL Book Club - The Murderbot Diaries Vol 1
events.description: Our high intermediate ESL Book Club will read The Murderbot Diaries Vol 1 by Martha Wells. This book club is best for high intermediate English learners. Students will read at home each week. Then we will meet as a group once a week to talk about the story, learn new vocabulary, and practice conversation. Book club will be led by Sheila Jurik. Meeting datesJanuary 12, 26 (No class Jan 19)February 2, 23 (No class Feb 9, 16)March 2, 9, 23, 30 (No class Mar 16)April 13, 20, 27 (No class Apr 6)Meeting time: 10:15am - 11:45amWhere: In the library - your book club leader will tell you which tables. Registration is open now! Book club is limited to 10 participants. Books will be provided for registered participants to keep. Please consider your schedule and do not register if you will miss more than one meeting. The Murderbot Diaries Vol 1 description:On a distant planet, a team of scientists are conducting surface tests, shadowed by their Company-supplied ‘droid ― a self-aware SecUnit that has hacked its own governor module, and refers to itself (though never out loud) as “Murderbot.” Scornful of humans, all it really wants is to be left alone long enough to figure out who it is (and to watch its favorite show in its downtime.) But when a neighboring mission goes dark, it’s up to the scientists and Murderbot to get to the truth.

events.title: Mint Hill Mystery Book Club
events.description: The Mint Hill Mystery Book Club is a long-standing club that meets the first Monday of each month from 2:00- 3:00pm to discuss new and classic Mysteries. Join us in March to discuss One By One by Freida McFadden. This program will be provided by Mint Hill library staff. Each month's discussion is led by a member of the group. For the complete list, click here: Mystery Book Club (Mint Hill). This event will be held in-person at the Mint Hill Library Branch.

events.title: The Friendship Club
events.description: Come to a drop-in activity program for adults with intellectual and/or developmental disabilities. This is a monthly get-together to have fun, create art and make friends. We'll have tables with activities you can choose from, such as jigsaw puzzles, coloring books, simple art projects and more! Registration not required. Reasonable accommodation for people with disabilities is available by request. Email access@kcls.org at least seven days before the event. Automated closed captioning is always available for online events.

events.title: Teen Book Bingo
events.description: Come out to play a classic with a bookish twist- Book Bingo! Find a book to browse for chances to win prizes! Don't know where to start? No problem! We have plenty of books here!

events.title: Movie Club Monday
events.description: Learn more about the book we read last month by watching the movie adaptation! You don't have to have read the book to attend. This month we will be watching Holes (2003). Have snacks and hang out!

events.title: My First Book Club
events.description: Drop in for your first book club! Read a story and do book-related activities. Best for kids ages 4-7!

events.title: Magic Tree House Book Club
events.description: Enjoy a few chapters of a Magic Tree House book, group discussion, games, and a themed activity each week. For elementary age children and their families. Registration for each session is encouraged to guarantee a spot, but walk-ins are welcome as supplies allow.

events.title: Friends of the Millbrae Library Book Club
events.description: Join us at the Millbrae Library on the first Monday of every month at 1:00 PM to discuss the month's chosen book. This is a monthly, ongoing discussion of works of all forms and genres; welcome to the most casual or avid readers alike.

events.title: Book Group
events.description: Join us for a lively discussion of select fiction and non-fiction books on the first Monday of the month. If the first Monday is a holiday, then the book group will meet on the second Monday.

location.name: Woodside
location.details: Held in the Learning Center inside the library.

events.title: Gourmet Graphics
events.description: Welcome to the book café where we’ll be tasting some of the best graphic novels to celebrate Will Eisner. Ages 8–adult. --- A book tasting is an opportunity to learn about new books in order to inspire and motivate readers. This tasting will feature graphic novels only. Will Eisner is one of the founders of the modern graphic novel. We’ll have information about him, the graphic novels that won, café snacks, and activities. No registration is needed, but it’s suggested in order to get a reminder.

events.title: Open Writers' Group: Level Up Your Writing with Sharon Short
events.description: Level Up Your Writing is an engaging workshop designed to help writers strengthen craft, boost creativity, and build confidence. Sharon Short shares practical strategies, inspiring insights, and actionable techniques drawn from her Writer’s Digest column and her decades of experience as a novelist and teacher. Perfect for writers of all levels looking to grow their skills. Sharon Short is the author of sixteen books, including her upcoming historical suspense novel Trouble Island (Minotaur Books, 2024). She is a contributing editor for Writer’s Digest, writing the “Level Up Your Writing (Life)” column and teaching for Writer’s Digest University. Writing as Jess Montgomery, she pens the award-winning Kinship Historical Mystery series. Sharon is a multi-award-winning writer and a popular speaker at libraries, book clubs, and writing groups.

events.title: Online Teen Book Club
events.description: Join us online and connect with other community readers. Each month, we’ll explore a new title ranging from bestselling teen books to graphic novels. Come together on Monday evenings to share thoughts, ask questions and jump into a thrilling story. A staff member will lead the group in a Zoom discussion. Participants who live in Johnson County will receive a copy of the book about a month before the meeting. Registration is required. A Library staff member will email registrants the day before with access instructions. No software download or account is required.Jan 5 – “The Inheritance Games” by Jennifer Lynn BarnesFeb 2 – “Carry On” by Rainbow RowellMarch 2 – “The Good Girl's Guide to Murder” by Holly JacksonApril 6 – “The Darkness Outside Us” by Eliot SchreferThis program will be hosted using the meeting software Zoom. A Johnson County Library staff member will contact registrants via email the day before the meeting with instructions on how to access the Zoom meeting. You do not need to download any software or create an account. For inquiries about accessibility and accommodations, please contact us at ask@jocolibrary.org or 913-826-4600 at least two weeks before the event.

events.title: Classics Book Club
events.description: Classic books transport us to distant times and places, but their stories are universal. Join us to read and discuss ancient and modern classics from around the world. January The Epic of GilgameshPrint · eBook February Oresteia by AeschylusPrint · Audiobook March Meditations by Marcus AureliusPrint · eBook · Audiobook April Twelfth Night by William ShakespearePrint · eBook · Audiobook May Beloved by Toni MorrisonPrint · eBook · Audiobook June The Bell Jar by Sylvia PlathPrint · eBook · Audiobook July An Artist of the Floating World by Kazuo IshiguroPrint · eBook · Audiobook August Selected Poems by RumiPrint · eBook · Audiobook September Selected Stories by Jorge Luis BorgesPrint · eBook October Song of Myself by Walt WhitmanPrint · eBook · Audiobook November Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass by Frederick DouglassPrint · eBook · Audiobook December Eugene Onegin by Alexander PushkinPrint · eBook

events.title: Black Comics Club
events.description: Black Comics Club Comics aren’t just stories on a page—they’re whole worlds waiting to be explored. At Black Comics Club, we dive into graphic novels by Black authors and artists, celebrating voices that bring bold new perspectives, unforgettable characters, and powerful storytelling to the medium.This month we will be discussing Bitch Planet by Kelly Sue DoConnick. Whether you’ve been collecting comics for years or you’re just picking up your first graphic novel, you’ll find a welcoming space to connect, share, and discover the depth and diversity of Black storytelling.

book.title: Bitch Planet by Kelly Sue DoConnick

events.title: Yazeba’s Bed & Breakfast
events.description: Join us for Hobbology – the (mostly) scientific study of hobbies and interests.🍄This March, we will enter the world of Yazeba's Bed & Breakfast. Choose one of the many unique player characters and become immersed in this cozy fantasy world. In this adventure, residents of the Bed & Breakfast will work together to craft a breakfast feast for the ages. 🍳This beginner-friendly role-playing game has a heavy focus on the story with very simple rules. No previous experience is needed to join in.✨ Play a cozy game🌿 Explore a new world🎲 Work together to solve puzzles🎂 Snacks provided!Whether you're a TTRPG expert or just want to try something new, join us for friendship and adventure! 🏰What is Hobbology?Hobbology is a monthly meetup akin to a book club with the goal of exploring new hobbies. We meet on the first Monday of the month.✨Try something new each month🏆 Build your hobby knowledge📍 Meet other students and working adultsWant to be notified about future events? Subscribe to our newsletter hereAccessibility Statement For in-person programs: Charlotte Mecklenburg Library is committed to providing accessible programs and events. This program will be offered in person at a library location. To request an accommodation, please contact us by phone or email at least one week prior to the program. Requests can be submitted by calling (704) 416-5204 or emailing lcarroll@cmlibrary.org.

events.title: English Learners Book Club
events.description: English Learners Book Club Improve your fluency, pronunciation and reading comprehension in a supportive small group environment. Native speakers and ESL students proficient in English are both welcomed. Articles, short stories, and short novels will be read. Every other Monday from 6PM-7PM. Audience: Adults. This month, join us virtually. This program will be provided by Independence Regional Library staff. For more information call 704-416-4833 or email aramos@cmlibrary.org. How to Join an Online ProgramThis event takes place on Zoom. When registering, please provide an email address so you can receive the link to connect to the virtual English Learners Book Club meeting. You’ll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting about 24 hours before the event. New to using Zoom? Check out these videos to help you get started: Zoom How-To Videos Looking for more technology resources? Check out this list! Want to be notified about future events? Subscribe to our newsletter here.

events.title: Readability Book Club
events.description: The Readability Book Club is a group for adults with disabilities that is run in partnership with Center for Independent Futures. We meet weekly on Mondays via Zoom. We read a new book (or books!) every 3 months. Our sessions run from January-March, April-June, July-September and October-December. Each meeting, we will recap what we have read so far, then the facilitator will read the next part of the book aloud. Afterwards, we will discuss what we just read. Our book for January-March will be: WILDCARD by Marie Lu.WildcardRegistration can be done here on the library website or via Center for Independent Futures.

We will also play character charades!

events.title: Mission Impossible Book Club, 1st Monday Virtual Group
events.description: This group meets every month from October - May to read and discuss Thomas Mann's "Tonio Kröger," Death in Venice, "Mario and the Magician," and The Magic Mountain. Find out more information here: https://epl.org/mission-impossibleIf registration is full and you wish to join, please contact Heather.

events.title: 星期一下午:西游记 (读书会)
events.description: A book club dedicated to "Journey to the West," the classic Chinese fiction. This club is designed for children who are fans of the story and is conducted entirely in Mandarin Chinese. The event is organized by dedicated teen volunteers from Lynbrook High School.小朋友们，你们听说过《西游记》吗？ 这是中国最有名的神话故事之一，讲述了一段惊险又有趣的旅程。在这个故事里，有聪明勇敢的孙悟空、善良慈悲的唐僧、憨厚搞笑的猪八戒，还有忠诚可靠的沙和尚。他们一路上经历了许多危险和考验，但靠着智慧和团结，成功完成了任务。这次旅程不仅是他们追寻经书的故事，更是一场关于勇气、坚持和成长的冒险！更多有关 美猴王系列丛书. 免费的亲子中文活動. 座位数量有限. 门票将在故事时间开始前 30 分钟在询问处领取。 圖書館中文资源: 大人最新中文书, 中文電子書, 非小說類電子書 (Overdrive) 有歡迎大家一起來借閱電子書. events.title: Point Reyes Book Club: Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, and Tomorrow
events.description: The Point Reyes Library Book Club will discuss Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, and Tomorrow by Gabrielle Zevin on Monday, March 2 from 7 to 8 pm. This book club meeting is online. Facilitator - Lorelei Sontag Contact: Mattie Ivy Leeds at 415-663-8375 or mattie.ivyleeds@marincounty.gov to register, or for more information. About the Book: Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, and Tomorrow by Gabrielle Zevin"A modern love story about two childhood friends, Sam, raised by an actress mother in LA's Koreatown, and Sadie, from the wealthy Jewish enclave of Beverly Hills, who reunite as adults to create video games, finding an intimacy in digital worlds that eludes them in their real lives, from the New York Times best-selling author of The Storied Life of A.J. Fikry"-- adapted from book jacket On a bitter-cold day, in the December of his junior year at Harvard, Sam Masur exits a subway car and sees, amid the hordes of people waiting on the platform, Sadie Green. He calls her name. For a moment, she pretends she hasn't heard him, but then, she turns, and a game begins: a legendary collaboration that will launch them to stardom.These friends, intimates since childhood, borrow money, beg favors, and, before even graduating college, they have created their first blockbuster, Ichigo. Overnight, the world is theirs. Not even twenty-five years old, Sam and Sadie are brilliant, successful, and rich, but these qualities won't protect them from their own creative ambitions or the betrayals of their hearts. Spanning thirty years, from Cambridge, Massachusetts, to Venice Beach, California, and lands in between and far beyond, Gabrielle Zevin's Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, and Tomorrow is a dazzling and intricately imagined novel that examines the multifarious nature of identity, disability, failure, the redemptive possibilities in play, and above all, our need to connect: to be loved and to love. Yes, it is a love story, but it is not one you have read before. ADA Accommodation Request | Solicitud de Adaptación ADA

events.title: Book Banter: Project Hail Mary
events.description: Join us for a fun, engaging discussion of Project Hail Mary, by Andy Weir, just in time for the movie release!--- Ryland Grace is the sole survivor on a desperate, last-chance mission—and if he fails, humanity and Earth itself will perish. Except that right now, he doesn’t know that. He can’t even remember his own name, let alone the nature of his assignment or how to complete it. All he knows is that he’s been asleep for a very, very long time. His crewmates dead, his memories fuzzily returning, Ryland realizes that an impossible task now confronts him. Hurtling through space on this tiny ship, it’s up to him to puzzle out an impossible scientific mystery—and conquer an extinction-level threat to our species. And with the clock ticking down and the nearest human being light-years away, he’s got to do it all alone. Or does he?

events.title: The In-Person Book Club - Daytime Edition
events.description: Join us on the 1st Tuesday of each month at 2:00 pm for The In-Person Davidson Branch Book Club! This month we will be discussing House in the Cerulean Sea by TJ Klune. This is the library's Community Read selection for March. I will have free copies available at our January and February meetings. From Publisher's Weekly: "Quirk and charm give way to a serious exploration of the dangers of complacency in this delightful, thought-provoking Orwellian fantasy from Klune. Caseworker Linus Baker of the Department in Charge of Magical Youths (DICOMY) believes he is doing right by the preternaturally gifted children placed in DICOMY-sanctioned orphanages. But Linus begins to question DICOMY's methods when the ominous Extremely Upper Management tasks Linus with evaluating the isolated Marsyas Island Orphanage and reporting not only on the island's extraordinary children--among them a female gnome, a blob of uncertain species who wants to be a bellhop, and a shy teenage boy who turns into a small dog when startled--but also on the orphanage master, Arthur Parnassus. The bonds Linus forms with the children and the romantic connection he feels for Arthur set Linus on a path toward redemption for the unwitting harm he caused as a cog in an uncaring bureaucratic machine. By turns zany and heartfelt, this tale of found family is hopeful to its core. Readers will revel in Klune's wit and ingenuity."This program will be provided by Davidson library staff. Information about this Group This book club reads across all genres. For a list of all 2026 selections please click here: In-Person Book Club (Davidson) Looking for more technology resources? Check out this list!

events.title: Intersecting Interests - Teen Diverse Media Club
events.description: The world is full of different cultures, artwork, and ways of life--and with the library, you can explore them without ever having to travel! Intersecting Interests is a laid-back media club for like-minded individuals who want to explore diverse media. We'll look at current events, featured diverse YA titles, and share media recommendations from art, poetry, film, and more with fun activities to explore while we discuss what we enjoyed.Topics include race, national origin, LGBTQ+ identity, socioeconomic class, physical and mental ability, education, health care, different religions, philosophies, and more in a supportive setting. You don't need to have read the book ahead of time to enjoy this program. Ages 13-18.Featured Titles and Activities for March-May:March: Wearing My Mother's Heart by Sophia Thakur + personal storytelling modeled after adinkra textiles (originating from Ghana, now widespread in West Africa and among African diaspora)April: As Long as the Lemon Trees Grow by Zoulfa Katouh + how to make rosewater and rose syrup, important for culinary, ritual, and cosmetic uses in Syria as well as many other countries across the Middle East, South Asia, and North Africa.May: The City Beautiful and Wrath Becomes Her by Aden Polydoros + mold a golem from clay to explore Jewish folklore*If there's a book or piece of media you'd like to see featured at a meeting, please feel to contact us with your great ideas!

events.title: Graphic Novel Book Club - Good Talk
events.description: Join us at Logan Square Branch for a discussion of the month's graphic novel selection. Current book club selections are available at the Logan Square Branch front desk.Good Talk - Mira Jacob“How brown is too brown?”“Can Indians be racist?”“What does real love between really different people look like?”Like many six-year-olds, Mira Jacob’s half-Jewish, half-Indian son, Z, has questions about everything. At first they are innocuous enough, but as tensions from the 2016 election spread from the media into his own family, they become much, much more complicated. Trying to answer him honestly, Mira has to think back to where she’s gotten her own answers: her most formative conversations about race, color, sexuality, and, of course, love. Written with humor and vulnerability, this deeply relatable graphic memoir is a love letter to the art of conversation—and to the hope that hovers in our most difficult questions. Accessibility Need sign language interpretation or other accessibility assistance for this event? Please call (312) 747-8184 or email access@chipublib.org to request accommodations. Requests must be made at least 14 business days before the event.

events.title: Book Clubs of EPL: The Herd
events.description: Love reading? Love to talk about books you've read? Come join us for lively discussions on all types of fiction and non-fiction. We'll feature different titles and authors each month. Come and share your impressions, thoughts and interpretations of a book we have all read. This month we will be reading: The Herd by Emily EdwardsYou should never judge how someone chooses to raise their child.Elizabeth and Bryony are polar opposites but their unexpected friendship has always worked. They're the best of friends, and godmothers to each other's daughters - because they trust that the safety of their children is both of their top priority.But what if their choice could harm your own child?Little do they know that they differ radically over one very important issue. And when Bryony, afraid of being judged, tells what is supposed to be a harmless white lie before a child's birthday party, the consequences are more catastrophic than either of them could ever have imagined . . .

events.title: Mystery Book Club
events.description: Meet with your neighbors and fellow mystery lovers on the first Tuesday night of each month for a lively discussion of classic and current mysteries. Read this month's selection, drop in and join the fun! For March 3 the club will be discussing The Castro Valley Reads book selection for 2026, Advice for Future Corpses (and Those Who Love Them) by Sallie Tisdale. Tisdale's book isn't built on a conventional plot; instead, it unfolds as a clear-eyed, compassionate exploration of something universal yet often avoided: dying. Drawing from her long experience as a palliative-care nurse, she guides readers through the practical, emotional, and spiritual realities of the end of life. What emerges is not a manual of dread, but an invitation to look directly at mortality with honesty and even tenderness. The magic of this book lies in Tisdale's voice. She moves with ease between intimate stories from the bedside, philosophical reflections, and grounded, often surprising advice. As she explores the fears, confusions, hopes, and small graces that accompany dying, she reveals the complex inner landscapes of patients, caregivers, and loved ones alike. Her writing is at once candid, lyrical, funny, and deeply humane. Through these interwoven perspectives, we're offered not just practical wisdom but a rare kind of companionship on a topic many of us struggle to face. Ultimately, Advice for Future Corpses is about how to meet mortality—with clarity, courage, humility, and love—and, in doing so, how to live more fully.Advice for Future Corpses* and Those Who Love Them Library staff may take photos, videos, or audio recordings at our events. Please tell us if you do not wish to be photographed, video-recorded, or audio-recorded. We will always respect your requests! An ASL (American Sign Language) interpreter or closed captioning can be provided for this program if requested at least seven (7) days in advance. For assistance, please contact your library or accessibility@aclibrary.org.

events.title: One Village, One Book
events.description: Our book club meets monthly at the library to discuss books set in Oakland and the Bay Area or by Bay Area authors. We select our books from a variety of genres and eras so you’re sure to find something you’re interested in. We’ll get to learn more about our city, meet some neighbors and discuss what we’ve read. This year we’re mostly alternating fiction and non-fiction books. Meetings are the first Tuesday of the month (note the change from 2025!) from 6:30-7:30pm. Come to one discussion, a few or all of them! No pre-registration or commitment is required – all we ask is that you’ve read at least some of the book and are ready to discuss it. Here’s our 2026 schedule: (Quoted descriptions are from the library catalog unless otherwise noted.) January 6, 2026: Sourdough by Robin Sloan (fiction)We’re kicking off the year with a quick read about the very Bay Area intersection of tech and food culture. Lois is an exhausted software engineer who is gifted a very special sourdough starter by her favorite bakers when they must flee the country. Pretty soon she’s part of a mysterious underground food scene at the former Alameda Naval Air Station. February 3, 2026: Family Style: Memories of An American From Vietnam by Thien Pham (graphic memoir)The book that got the most votes from our members on our year-end poll! “Told through the lens of meaningful food and meals, this graphic novel chronicles the author’s childhood immigration to America, where food takes on new meaning as he and his family search for belonging, for happiness and for the American dream.” Pham is a graphic novelist, comic artist and educator based in Oakland. March 3, 2026: Deep Care: The Radical Activists Who Provided Abortions, Defied the Law, and Fought to Keep Clinics Open by Angela Hume (non-fiction)“The story of the radical feminist networks who worked outside the law to defend abortion. Deep Care follows generations of activists and clinicians who orbited the Women’s Choice clinic in Oakland from the early 1970s until 2010, as they worked underground and above ground, in small cells and broad coalitions and across political movements with grit, conviction, and allegiances of great trust to do what they believed needed to be done–despite the law, when required.” April 7, 2026: Moonglow by Michael Chabon (fiction)“A man bears witness to his grandfather’s deathbed confessions, which reveal his family’s long-buried history and his involvement in a mail-order novelty company, World War II and the space program.” Most of it isn’t set in Oakland, but it is the only book on this list that specifically mentions Montclair Library! May 5, 2026: Automatic Noodle by Annalee Newitz (science fiction)Our May read is a slim 163 pages, but packed with interesting ideas. This book is super popular as of December 2025, so you might want to get your hold in early. “In this semicozy tale set in a dystopian near future, robots open their own restaurant, build an unusual found family and achieve personal growth. A few years after the war that led to California’s secession from the United States, four robots awake in the flooded San Francisco takeout place where they were contracted to work.” (Kirkus) “Emboldened by newly granted civil rights from the California government, the bots reboot their lives in classic Bay Area form: by opening a noodle shop…In many ways, Newitz’s near-future San Francisco resembles today’s city, with not-so-subtle nods to AI anxieties, queer identity and the modern-day immigrant experience. It is, in the words of KQED’s Alexis Madrigal, ‘The most San Francisco book that has ever been or could ever have been written.’” (Leah Worthington) (Ebook listed separately) June 2, 2026: Moneyball by Michael Lewis (non-fiction)Baseball season is in full swing, which makes this the perfect time to read Michael Lewis’s nuanced exploration of “how Billy Beene, the general manager of the Oakland Athletics, used a new kind of thinking to build a successful and winning baseball team without spending enormous sums of money.” July 7, 2026: Girls Girls Girls by Shoshana von Blanckensee (fiction)In the summer of 1996, best friends (and secret girlfriends), Hannah and Sam drive from “New York, to the fabled queer paradise of San Francisco, free from the harsh gazes of their neighbors and the stifling demands of Hannah’s devout Orthodox Jewish mother. In San Francisco, they will finally be together as a real couple, out in the open, around other queer people.” But soon they’re working at a strip club, meeting new people and trying to figure out who just they are. August 4, 2026: Power Hungry: Women of the Black Panther Party and Freedom Summer and Their Fight to Feed a Movement by Suzanne Cope (non-fiction)Journey back with us to the summer of 1969 with the story of the free breakfast movement, grocery giveaways and other nurturing mutual aid programs started by the Black Panthers. “NYU writing professor Cope rescues two female activists from obscurity in this intriguing look at the role that food played in the civil rights and Black Power movements.” If you read One Crazy Summer with us in 2025, you’ll enjoy learning the backstory to the Panthers’ food program. September 1, 2026: Kasher in the Rye by Moshe Kasher (memoir)Go back to school with this “hilarious memoir about the absurdity of addiction.” “When he was a young boy, Kasher’s mother took him on a vacation to the West Coast. Well it was more like an abduction…They moved to Oakland, California. That’s where the real fun begins, in the war zone of Oakland Public Schools. Those early years read like part Augusten Burroughs, part David Sedaris, with a touch of Jim Carrol….Brutally honest and laugh-out-loud funny, Kasher…finds humor in even the most horrifying situations.” October 6, 2026: 107 Days by Kamala Harris (memoir)Hopefully by October the miles-long hold list for this book will have settled down enough for you to get a copy! “For the first time, and with surprising and revealing insights, Kamala Harris tells the story of one of the wildest and most consequential presidential campaigns in American history.” (NPR) November 3, 2026: The Giveaway: The Clay Blackburn Story by Owen Hill (crime fiction)We have something noir-ish by an Oakland author for those long November nights. “Hill’s crime fiction is whip-smart, stylish, subversive, hilarious and just dripping with East Bay color, culture and landmarks. Sweet and sour like a perfect Negroni, Hill has invented a new kind of East Bay Noir — the fog rolls in late, the golden afternoon glow somehow both luxurious and ominous in the class war that never sleeps.” (Recommendation from Tally Ho! Books via Oaklandside) December 1, 2026: Sign My Name to Freedom by Betty Reid Soskin (memoir)Reid Soskin, famous for being the oldest park ranger in the history of the National Park Service while working at the Rosie the Riveter National Park in Richmond, has been witness to a wide sweep of American history. She grew up in the Bay Area, raised four kids, ran a record store in Berkeley and more. “Betty just turned 104 and her memoir gives a fascinating look at African Americans migration, the Rosie the Riveter story, and beyond through the Civil Rights era.” (recommender) (Ebook and audiobook listed separately) « See our 2025 books here »« See our 2024 books here »« See our 2023 books here »Learn more about Montclair Library and its Friends group, FOML, here: About | Friends of Montclair Library

events.title: Intermediate ESL Book Club - One Foot in the Grape
events.description: Carla's intermediate ESL Book Club will read One Food in the Grap by Carlene O'Neil. This book club is best for intermediate English learners. Students will read at home each week. Then we will meet as a group once a week to talk about the story, learn new vocabulary, and practice conversation. Book club will be led by Carla Passero. Meeting dates: January 13, 20, 27; February 3, 10, 17, 24; March 3, 24, 31. (No class March 10 or March 17).Meeting time: Tuesdays, 7:00pm - 8:00pmWhere: CCC Room next to Member Services DeskRegistration is open now! Book club is limited to 8 participants. Books will be provided at the first meeting for registered participants to keep, If you do not show up at the first meeting and have not made arrangements with the tutor, we will give your spot to the next learner on the wait list. Please consider your schedule and do not register if you will miss more than one meeting. About the book:One Foot in the Grape is a cozy mystery about ex-photojournalist Penny Lively, who inherits a California winery, only to get tangled in murder when her neighbor's wine is sabotaged and a staff member ends up dead in a grape crusher, making her niece the prime suspect, forcing Penny to solve the crime before her family is ruined. It's the first in the Cypress Cove Mystery series, blending wine country charm with amateur sleuthing and danger.

events.title: Sci-Fi & Fantasy Book Club
events.description: To celebrate Women's History Month we will be discussing The Left Hand of Darkness by Ursula K. Le Guin. Sign up at the adult reference desk to get a copy.A lone human emissary to Winter, an alien world whose inhabitants can choose—and change—their gender. His goal is to facilitate Winter's inclusion in a growing intergalactic civilization. But to do so he must bridge the gulf between his own views and those of the completely dissimilar culture that he encounters.Embracing the aspects of psychology, society, and human emotion on an alien world, The Left Hand of Darkness stands as a landmark achievement in the annals of intellectual science fiction. Nebula Award Winner, 1969 and Hugo Award Winner, 1970.

events.description: Get some exercise and read the latest story installed at the StoryWalk in Central Park. The winter themed story is called Except Antarctica, written and illustrated by Todd Sturgell. Follow turtle and learn about animals found on every continent except Antarctica!The San Ramon StoryWalk® is a permanent feature in San Ramon’s Central Park. The 20-station project features a new book four times a year. The San Ramon StoryWalk® project is a partnership with the Rotary Club of San Ramon, the City of San Ramon, the San Ramon Library Foundation, and the Library. The Central Park StoryWalk® begins near the Alcosta parking lot to the right of the playground, ending at the Community Center’s rear fountain. The StoryWalk Project was created by Anne Ferguson of Montpelier, VT and developed in collaboration with the Kellogg-Hubbard Library. StoryWalk is a registered service mark owned by Ms. Ferguson.

events.description: Come join the Lunch & Munch Book Club, our contemporary fiction & non-fiction book club at Independence Regional Library, meeting the first Wednesday of the month, Noon-1:30PM in the Community Room. Bring your own lunch or snack and opinions. Request a copy of this month's selection from the book selection list in the library catalog and register for the program! March's Book Selection is: Carnegie's Maid by Marie Benedict Synopsis: "Clara Kelley is not who they think she is. She's not the experienced Irish maid who was hired to work in one of Pittsburgh's grandest households. She's a poor farmer's daughter with nowhere to go and nothing in her pockets. But the other woman with the same name has vanished, and pretending to be her just might get Clara some money to send back home. If she can keep up the ruse, that is."Looking for the book? Check out the book club selections here and make a request for the upcoming title. View, print or download a flyer of the 2026 book club dates and selections here. This program will be provided by Independence Regional Library staff. For more information email astewart@cmlibrary.org or call 704-416-4800. Information about this Group The Lunch & Munch Book Club meets each month to share thoughts on contemporary fiction and non-fiction titles. Click here to register for upcoming dates! Programs will be held in the Independence Regional Library Community Room Please register by 2 days before the event. Want to be notified about future events? Subscribe to our newsletter here.

events.description: Join fellow yarn and textile enthusiasts to share inspiration, ideas, and stories from our experiences as knitters, crocheters, and crafters. Meet up with other knitters or crocheters for self-directed projects in yarn and thread. Bring your own project to work on--no supplies are provided. While you're here, check out our many crafting books with knitting and crocheting projects to try. We meet weekly, every Wednesday afternoon from 1:00pm to 3:00 pm. This program will take place indoors at the North County Regional Library. Indoor programs will be operating at a reduced attendance capacity and will include social distancing based on the library space. Want to be notified about future events? Subscribe to our newsletter here. For the safety of staff and other program participants, please stay home if you feel sick, are experiencing symptoms of COVID-19, have a confirmed case of COVID-19, are awaiting COVID-19 test results, or have recently been exposed to someone with COVID-19.​

events.description: 알바니팍 도서관 한국어 북클럽에 초대합니다. 이번 달에는 류드밀라 울리츠카야의 <행복한 장례식>을 읽고 토론합니다. 루드밀라 율리츠카야의 소설 ‘행복한 장례식’(Веселые похороны)은 우리 모두의 삶의 방식을 되돌아보게 만드는 작품입니다. 1991년 8월, 뉴욕시의 아파트에서 러시아 이민자들이 ‘알릭’이라는 임종 직전의 예술가 주위에 모입니다. 성공하지 못한 화가인 알릭은 친구들에 둘러싸여 죽음을 기다립니다. 러시아 이민자들이자 유태인들인 이 친구들은 보드카를 마시면서 왁자지껄 떠들어대면서 알릭의 마지막을 함께하고 있는데, 때 마침 텔레비전을 통해 모스크바의 쿠데타를 시청하게 되면서 이들은 러시아인이 된다는 것이 무엇을 의미하는지를 생각하게 됩니다. 이 책은 삶과 죽음, 사랑과 비탄, 가정과 이민에 대한 통찰력으로 가득 차 있습니다. events.title: Virtual Author Talk: Michael Perry
events.description: Join us for a conversation with bestselling author and humorist Michael Perry, whose wide‑ranging work captures the humor, heartbreak, and everyday magic of rural communities. In his memoir Population: 485, Perry introduces readers to unforgettable small‑town characters, from a pistol‑packing vigilante to a cross‑eyed butcher, while navigating fires, wrecks, bar fights, and moments of quiet tenderness that reveal the soul of his hometown. His fiction debut, Jesus Cow, brings the same blend of wit and sincerity to a modern tale of faith and chaos, following Harley Jackson as he contends with love, land‑hungry developers, and a calf born with the image of Jesus Christ on its flank. Together, these works showcase Perry’s gift for finding the extraordinary in ordinary lives.This program is part of Santa Clara County Library District's celebration of Silicon Valley Reads. ---The Santa Clara County Library District is proud to present a free virtual author‑talk series featuring bestselling, award‑winning, and acclaimed writers from around the world, offering live Q&A sessions two to three times a month. Event links are sent about 24 hours in advance (or upon late registration), recordings are available for a limited time, and a full list of upcoming programs can be found here. ---For accessibility accommodations (ex. ASL), please fill out the online form at sccld.org/accessibility 7+days prior to the event. If you need assistance with the form, speak with a staff member at your local library, call (408) 540-3945, or email us at ask@lib.sccgov.org.

events.title: Men's BYOB (Bring Your Own Book) Book Club
events.description: Join us on the 1st Wednesday of each month at 6pm for the Men's BYOB (Bring Your Own Book) book club! Bring any book you’re currently reading — fiction, nonfiction, audiobook, graphic novel, anything — and join other men for a relaxed, conversation-driven book club. Instead of everyone reading the same title, each participant shares what they’re reading, why they chose it, and whether they’d recommend it. It’s a low-pressure way to discover new books, connect with others, and build a reading community. Men are strongly encouraged to join, but all people are welcome. This program will be provided by North County Regional Library staff. Information about this Group What to Expect: Everyone brings a book they’re currently reading or recently finished Each person shares a 2–3 minute mini-review Open discussion about reading interests, life topics, and book recommendations A casual, supportive space to talk or simply listen Perfect for busy schedules—no assigned reading How to Join an Online Program This event takes place online using Zoom. Please include your email address to receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting at least 24 hours prior to the start of this event. New to using Zoom? Check out these videos to help you get started: Zoom How-To Videos or check out this list for more resources. Accessibility Statement For online programs: Charlotte Mecklenburg Library is committed to providing accessible programs and events. This program will be offered online using the Zoom video conferencing platform. Closed Captioning and Full Transcript will be available during the program. To request an additional accommodation, please contact us by phone or email at least one week prior to the program. Requests can be submitted by calling (704) 416-6000 or emailing ksloan@cmlibrary.org.

events.title: Virtual Next Chapter Book Club: Top Story
events.description: You're invited to join the Saint Paul Public Library's Next Chapter Book Club as we read Top Story by Kelly Yang. Since the fall of 2016, Saint Paul Public Library has been a Next Chapter Book Club affiliate. Next Chapter Book Club offers community-based book clubs for adolescents and adults with intellectual and developmental disabilities. Our members (including some who cannot read) love the way books transport them to different worlds where they meet interesting characters and learn about exciting new things. Taking that journey with a group of friends makes it even more delightful and fun. Join us online (click this link to connect to the virtual book club) Wednesdays 5-6 pm until we reach the end of the book. Estimated end date in March. Contact Erin at erin.zolotukhin-ridgway@ci.stpaul.mn.us with questions. This book will be shared online during book club.

events.title: Boos & Brews at Bellbrook Brewing Company: Episode Thirteen
events.description: RESCHEDULED FROM FEBRUARY Do you want to explore what the horror genre has to offer? Boos and Brews is for you! Join us at the Bellbrook Brewing Company! for Adults 18+.-- This month we are reading Episode Thirteen by Craig DiLouie. Fade to Black is the newest hit ghost hunting reality TV show. It's led by husband and wife team Matt and Claire Kirklin and features a dedicated crew of ghost-hunting experts. Episode Thirteen takes them to Matt's holy grail: the Paranormal Research Foundation. This crumbling, derelict mansion holds secrets and clues about the bizarre experiments that took place there in the 1970s. It's also, undoubtedly, haunted, and Matt hopes to use their scientific techniques and high tech gear to prove it. But, as the house begins to slowly reveal itself to them, proof of an afterlife might not be everything Matt dreamed of. A story told in broken pieces, in tapes, journals, correspondence, and research files, this is the story of Episode Thirteen--and how everything went horribly wrong. Pick up your copy at the Winters Community Library Reference Desk. Boos and Brews meets in the loft at Bellbrook Brewing Company, located at 26 East Franklin Street, Bellbrook, Ohio 45305. A variety of beverages are available for purchase from Bellbrook Brewing Company, To receive updates regarding this event, please register.

events.title: Virtual Talk with Best Selling Author  Doug Tallamy
events.description: New York Times Best Selling Author Doug Tallamy Nature's Best HopeHomegrown National Park Our parks, preserves, and remaining wildlands – no matter how grand in scale – are too small and separated from one another to sustain the native trees, plants, insects, and animals on which our ecosystems depend. We can fix this problem by practicing conservation outside of wildlands, where we live, work, shop, farm, and ranch. Thus, the concept for Homegrown National Park: a national challenge to create diverse ecosystems in our yards, communities, farms, and surrounding lands by reducing lawn, planting native, and removing invasives. The goal of HNP is to create a national movement to restore 20 million acres with natives, an area representing of what is now in lawn, as well as millions more acres in agriculture and woodlots. We are at a critical point where we are losing so many native plant and animal species that our life support systems are in jeopardy. However, if many people make small changes, we can restore healthy ecological networks and weather the changes ahead. Doug Tallamy is the T. A. Baker Professor of Agriculture in the Department of Entomology and Wildlife Ecology at the University of Delaware, where he has authored 118 research publications and has taught insect related courses for 45 years. Chief among his research goals is to better understand the many ways insects interact with plants and how such interactions determine the diversity of animal communities. His books include Bringing Nature Home, The Living Landscape, co-authored with Rick Darke, Nature's Best Hope, a New York Times Best Seller, The Nature of Oaks, winner of the American Horticultural Society’s 2022 book award, and his latest book How Can I Help. In 2021 he cofounded Homegrown National Park with Michelle Alfandari (HomegrownNationalPark.org). His awards include recognition from The Garden Writer’s Association, Audubon, The National Wildlife Federation, Allegheny College, Ecoforesters, The Garden Club of America, The Herb Society, Santa Barbara Botanic Garden, and The American Horticultural Association.

A woman becomes dissatisfied with her physical appearance, but after a visit from the ghost of her late aunt, she learns the hidden power of her body hair. events.title: Better Off Read Book Group- All about love
events.description: In this landmark book, bell hooks explores the question "What is love?" Her answers strike at both the mind and heart. Disputing that the ideal love is infused with sex and desire, she provides a new path to love that is sacred, redemptive, and healing for individuals and for a nation. All About Love is a powerful, timely affirmation of just how profoundly love and community can change hearts and minds for the better.The City of Evanston is committed to promoting a Citywide culture of accessibility and inclusivity. To request an accommodation for a program, service, or activity, please call 847-866-2919 to make an ADA service request or fill out a request form online.

events.title: Mystery Book Club
events.description: Join the book club to meet, mingle and chat with other literature lovers. Experience the pleasure of reading and discovering new mystery books and authors. For March, the Mystery Book Club is reading The Locked Ward by Sarah Pekkanen. "Was it... Bitter, all-consuming jealousy? Pathological sibling rivalry? Pure insanity? Whatever the cause-and everyone has a theory-it's the Crime of the Decade when glamorous Georgia Cartwright, who was adopted as a newborn, is accused of killing the biological daughter of her wealthy, Southern family. Georgia is locked in a psychiatric institution where the most violent offenders are held while she awaits trial. The only words she whispers when her estranged twin sister Amanda visits are, "I didn't do it. You've got to get me out of here." Amanda doesn't trust Georgia, but she can't abandon her in a place so eerie and menacing that it seems to exist in another dimension. Is Georgia the victim of a powerful family that's so depraved murder is the least of their crimes? Or is Amanda being led down a path of madness into the web of a master manipulator?" We meet on the first Wednesday of each month at 6:30 – 7:45 PM in the upstairs Conference Room. Contact the Library for more information at kw@hcpl.net

events.title: Fantastic Fourth Grade Book Club

Please remember to bring your Alameda County Library card (or the card number) with you in order to check out the book for next month's meeting. events.description: This month, the group will be discussing The Raven Tower, by Ann Leckie. Join us for a virtual book group meeting for fans of speculative fiction! To participate, click on the REGISTER button on this page, and include your email address. Once you have registered here, you will be sent the meeting ID and password. You do not have to appear via video if you don't want to - you can join using audio and chat only, if that is your preference. At the scheduled meeting time, click on the link you have been sent to join.

events.title: Silent Book Club
events.description: Do you find it difficult to find time to read? Do you hate reading assigned books? Are you anxious in a traditional book club setting? If you answered yes to any of these, then check out Silent Book Club. A new type of book club, where there's no assigned reading and all readers are welcome.BYOBook (print, eBooks, audiobooks, textbooks, comic books, etc.) and settle in for an hour of silent, sustained reading. At the end of the hour, attendees can discuss what they're reading—or not! A fun way to hear about what others are reading and share what you're reading. Best of all, there's dedicated time each month to read something that interests you. Silent Book Club meets the first Wednesday of the month in Creativity Commons on Level 1. Any person needing an accommodation for a disability to access the benefits of the Library’s services, programs, or activities under the Americans with Disabilities Act should contact the Library by telephone at (972) 292-5669, by email at library@friscotexas.gov, or in writing, not less than five (5) business days prior to the program.

Follow turtle and learn about animals found on every continent except Antarctica!The San Ramon StoryWalk® is a permanent feature in San Ramon’s Central Park. The 20-station project features a new book four times a year. The San Ramon StoryWalk® project is a partnership with the Rotary Club of San Ramon, the City of San Ramon, the San Ramon Library Foundation, and the Library. The Central Park StoryWalk® begins near the Alcosta parking lot to the right of the playground, ending at the Community Center’s rear fountain. The StoryWalk Project was created by Anne Ferguson of Montpelier, VT and developed in collaboration with the Kellogg-Hubbard Library. StoryWalk is a registered service mark owned by Ms. Ferguson.

events.title: Intermediate ESL Book Club - Chains (The Seeds of America Trilogy)
events.description: Our intermediate ESL Book Club will read Chains (The Seeds of America Trilogy) by Laurie Halse Anderson. This book club is best for intermediate English learners. Students will read at home each week. Then we will meet as a group once a week to talk about the story, learn new vocabulary, and practice conversation. Book club will be led by Roberta Linsky. Meeting dates: February 26; March 5, 12, 19; April 2, 16; May 7. (No class March 26; April 9, 23, 30.)Meeting time: Thursdays from 10:00am - 11:00amWhere: Tables by the wall posters Registration is open now! Book club is limited to 10 participants. Books will be provided for registered participants to keep. Please consider your schedule and do not register if you will miss more than one meeting. Book description:As the Revolutionary War begins, thirteen-year-old Isabel wages her own fight...for freedom. Promised freedom upon the death of their owner, she and her sister, Ruth, in a cruel twist of fate become the property of a malicious New York City couple, the Locktons, who have no sympathy for the American Revolution and even less for Ruth and Isabel. When Isabel meets Curzon, a slave with ties to the Patriots, he encourages her to spy on her owners, who know details of British plans for invasion. She is reluctant at first, but when the unthinkable happens to Ruth, Isabel realizes her loyalty belongs to whoever can provide her with freedom.

events.title: The Genre Jumpers Book Club
events.description: Read a new genre every month! This month, we explore Fantasy and Science Fiction with N.K. Jemisin's Hugo Award-winning novel, The Fifth Season. The story is set on the Stillness, a world constantly threatened by apocalyptic climate disasters known as "Seasons." It follows three women—all powerful earth-manipulators called Orogenes—as their lives converge during a cataclysmic event. A complex and groundbreaking tale of power, survival, and a society built on oppression. Copies will be available at the Information Desk, and the e-book and e-audiobook versions are on CloudLibrary. events.description: Connect with others over lively conversation ~ while we adventure together, through our reading choices! Thursday, March 5th, come share your thoughts on our current selection: Daughters of Shandong by Eve J. Chung. This selection is a propulsive, unique novel about a mother and her daughters’ harrowing escape during the Communist revolution by debut author Eve J. Chung, based on her family story. “Throw open the doors of your heart for the lionhearted girls of Chung’s gripping debut . . . they are heroines for the ages."—People You can email us at Belmont for any additional info you might need: belmont@smcl.org Or simply stop by if you'd like to see if we still have copies of this selection, which are typically held behind the Info Desk for each book club. And if you haven't had time to read this particular book? No worries! Still join us for a lovely afternoon of ever evolving camaraderie & fellowship as we discuss together what everyone's been reading, which may include other genres or time periods. Hope to see you in March at the Twin Pines Community Center ~

events.title: Bookin' and Cookin': The Book Club for Troublesome Women by Marie Bostwick
events.description: Join us for a discussion of The Book Club for Troublesome Women. Bring food related to the book to share.---By 1960s standards, Margaret Ryan is living the American woman's dream. She has a husband, three children, a station wagon, and a home in Concordia - one of Northern Virginia's most exclusive and picturesque suburbs. She has a standing invitation to the neighborhood coffee klatch, and now, thanks to her husband, a new subscription to A Woman's Place - a magazine that tells housewives like Margaret exactly who to be and what to buy. On paper, she has it all. So why doesn't that feel like enough?

events.title: Book Banter: Project Hail Mary
events.description: Join us for a fun, engaging discussion of Project Hail Mary, by Andy Weir, just in time for the movie release! --- Ryland Grace is the sole survivor on a desperate, last-chance mission—and if he fails, humanity and Earth itself will perish. Except that right now, he doesn’t know that. He can’t even remember his own name, let alone the nature of his assignment or how to complete it. All he knows is that he’s been asleep for a very, very long time. His crewmates dead, his memories fuzzily returning, Ryland realizes that an impossible task now confronts him. Hurtling through space on this tiny ship, it’s up to him to puzzle out an impossible scientific mystery—and conquer an extinction-level threat to our species. And with the clock ticking down and the nearest human being light-years away, he’s got to do it all alone. Or does he?

events.title: Making Stories
events.description: Children ages 8 to 12 are invited to join a club that meets on the first Thursday of each month from 3:30-5 pm to write, illustrate, make, and tell your own stories. This is a workshop, where kids can work alone, in pairs, or in small groups to write and illustrate stories. Follow a prompt, do a fun writing or drawing exercise, or free write. Create a book, a zine, a comic, a story, a kamishibai, a play, or whatever! We'll set a date for people who want to read aloud their finished stories and celebrate, and we welcome stories to be added into the library collection. Drop in, no registration required. New members always welcome. Please note: In January, we'll meet on the 2nd Thursday. Get accessibility information.

events.title: Kids Culture Club
events.description: Embark on a global adventure by attending Culture Club on the first Thursday of every month! In each session, young explorers will learn more about an important culture through an engaging activity, such as a craft, game, and/or books and audiovisual media. From making traditional art to viewing a new film, each gathering is a fun-filled journey that fosters curiosity and appreciation for the world’s rich diversity. Perfect for ages 6-11, Culture Club invites kids to connect, create, and celebrate together—one culture at a time! No registration required and all materials will be provided.This month, we're exploring Greek history, culture, and heritage by making scratch art in the shape of Greek vases!

events.title: Silent Book Club
events.description: Looking for some dedicated time to read, but don't want to be told WHAT to read? Try out this Silent Book Club! You bring what you're reading, whether it's for another book club or the door stopper you've been working through for months, and you read for an hour. There will be snacks and drinks. We will meet in the Reading Garden. In case of rain, we will meet instead in the Twain meeting room. Registration not required but if you sign up, you'll get a reminder prior to the event!

events.title: Inclusive Book Club with AAC (Online Event)
events.description: Hello Book Club Families, Book of the Week: A to Z Mysteries: The Canary CaperC is for Canary . . . Green Lawn has a pet problem! Dink’s neighbor can’t find her canary. Ruth Rose’s cat, Tiger, has also disappeared. Then the kids hear about two more missing critters. Is there a pet-napper in town? Dink, Josh, and Ruth Rose are on the case! About Our Book Club: Each week, an AAC user hosts our sessions, and a librarian reads our story. After each reading, we enjoy an activity or game connected to the book, celebrating representation, creativity, and the many wonderful ways people communicate. We celebrate all forms of communication—AAC, speech, gestures, and expressions—and follow a Floortime-inspired approach that centers on meeting readers where they are and building joyful shared experiences. When applicable, a visual schedule will be emailed 24 hours before each session to help our readers follow along. Special thanks to Ron Roy and Penguin Random House for allowing us to read A to Z Mysteries: The Canary Caper in our virtual book club.

book.title: A to Z Mysteries: The Canary Caper

events.description: This themed, literacy-based drop in program is chock full of activities to help prepare your child for school and beyond. events.title: Intermediate ESL Book Club - Skylark
events.description: Our intermediate ESL Book Club will read Sarah, Plain and Tall by Patricia MacLachlan. This book club is best for intermediate English learners. Students will read at home each week. Then we will meet as a group once a week to talk about the story, learn new vocabulary, and practice conversation. Book club will be led by Elaine Hilbelink. Meeting dates: February 27; March 6, 13, 20, 27; April 3 Meeting time: Fridays 10am - 11am Where: Literacy Table Registration is open now! Book club is limited to 10 participants. Books will be provided for registered participants to keep. Please consider your schedule and do not register if you will miss more than one meeting. Skylark description:The second book in the series that began with the Newbery Medal–winning Sarah, Plain and Tall by Patricia MacLachlan. Sarah came to the prairie from Maine to marry Papa. But that summer, a drought turned the land dry and brown. Fires swept across the fields and coyotes came to the well in search of water. So Sarah took Anna and Caleb back east, where they would be safe. Papa stayed behind. He would not leave his land. Maine was beautiful, but Anna missed home, and Papa. And as the weeks went by, she began to wonder what would happen if the rains never came. Would she and Caleb and Sarah and Papa ever be a family again?

events.title: Intermediate ESL Book Club - The Game
events.description: Our intermediate ESL Book Club will read The Game by Monica Hughes. This book club is best for intermediate English learners. Students will read at home each week. Then we will meet as a group once a week to talk about the story, learn new vocabulary, and practice conversation. Book club will be led by Rianne Hastie Adams. Meeting dates: February 27; March 6, 20, 27; April 3, 17. (No class March 13 and April 10.)Meeting time: Fridays 11:30am - 12:30pm Where: Literacy Table Registration is open now! Book club is limited to 10 participants. Books will be provided for registered participants to keep. Please consider your schedule and do not register if you will miss more than one meeting. The Game description:It’s the year 2154. Lisse and her friends have been deemed unemployable in the eyes of society. Now they must scavenge the disintegrating city for food and shelter, just to make ends meet. But their dismal existence starts to look up when Lisse and her friends are invited to participate in The Game, a virtual reality experience where they are challenged to survive. But over time, the line between reality and fantasy starts to blur. What started as a simple exercise quickly becomes a test of endurance, trust, and their will to live.

events.title: Trilingual Book Club
events.description: Join us for a meaningful, engaging discussion hosted in English, Farsi, and French. In March, we'll discuss Alice's Adventures in Wonderland by Lewis Carroll, and in April we'll dive into Where the Wild Things Are by Maurice Sendak. Participants will reflect on the messages of each book and share their insights in a supportive environment. Presented in partnership with Lantern Book Club. Teens welcome. برای یک گفت‌وگوی جذاب و معنا‌دار به زبان‌های انگلیسی، فارسی و فرانسوی، به ما بپیوندید.در ماه مارس، کتاب «آلیس در سرزمین عجایب» و در ماه آوریل، «جایی که موجودات وحشی هستند» را بررسی خواهیم کرد.شرکت‌کنندگان درباره پیام هر کتاب فکر می‌کنند و دیدگاه‌های خود را در فضایی دوستانه و حمایتی به اشتراک می‌گذارند.این برنامه با همکاری گروه Lantern Book Club برگزار می‌شود.نوجوانان عزیز، خوش‌آمدید!Pour une discussion enrichissante et captivante en anglais, farsi et français, rejoignez-nous. En mars, nous discuterons de Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland et en avril de Where the Wild Things Are. Les participantes réfléchiront aux messages de chaque livre et partageront leurs points de vue dans un environnement chaleureux et bienveillant. Cet événement est organisé en partenariat avec le Lantern Book Club. Chers adolescents, bienvenue !

events.title: Fletcher Hills Library Book Club
events.description: This month we will be discussing "The Only One Left" by Riley Sager. About the book:Bestselling author Riley Sager returns with a Gothic chiller about a young caregiver assigned to work for a woman accused of a Lizzie Borden-like massacre decades earlier.At seventeen, Lenora HopeHung her sister with a ropeNow reduced to a schoolyard chant, the Hope family murders shocked the Maine coast one bloody night in 1929. While most people assume seventeen-year-old Lenora was responsible, the police were never able to prove it. Other than her denial after the killings, she has never spoken publicly about that night, nor has she set foot outside Hope’s End, the cliffside mansion where the massacre occurred.Stabbed her father with a knifeTook her mother’s happy lifeIt’s now 1983, and home-health aide Kit McDeere arrives at a decaying Hope’s End to care for Lenora after her previous nurse fled in the middle of the night. In her seventies and confined to a wheelchair, Lenora was rendered mute by a series of strokes and can only communicate with Kit by tapping out sentences on an old typewriter. One night, Lenora uses it to make a tantalizing offer—I want to tell you everything.“It wasn’t me,” Lenora saidBut she’s the only one not deadAs Kit helps Lenora write about the events leading to the Hope family massacre, it becomes clear there’s more to the tale than people know. But when new details about her predecessor’s departure come to light, Kit starts to suspect Lenora might not be telling the complete truth—and that the seemingly harmless woman in her care could be far more dangerous than she first thought.

Bring a cutting or small plant you would like to swap!This program is presented by the Master Gardeners of Mecklenburg County in partnership with Mountain Island Library branch. About Community Read Community Read is Charlotte Mecklenburg Library’s annual, community-wide book club—an invitation to connect through a shared story. Each year’s book selection inspires programs, community conversations, and events that explore timely and meaningful themes. This year’s title The House in the Cerulean Sea by TJ Klune explores themes of found family, belonging, and self-acceptance. Please join us at programs and events all month long and pick up your free copy at any Charlotte Mecklenburg Library location, while supplies last. Learn more at cmlibrary.org/community-read

events.title: Graphic Novel Club: Go-Man! Volume 1, Champion of Earth
events.description: Graphic novel pick for this month is: Go-Man! Volume 1, Champion of Earth by Hamish Steele. We will have limited copies available for check out at the Ask Me Desk. Description from library catalog:"Lonely latchkey kid Tobi, an autistic boy, dreams of growing up to fight the giant monsters that plague his city, exactly like his dad does, but when Tobi stumbles upon the power to turn into the colossal superhero Go-Man, he realizes he must learn to accept help from new friends to save the day. As a superhero, Tobi becomes super popular thanks to his new friend Grace's social media campaign! But being Go-Man drains him of all his energy, and he's forced to retreat into his bedroom for days. When the monsters keep coming, he feels he needs to help fight them and protect his friends, despite what is best for himself. On top of the chaos the monsters bring, the city's Robug Squad, his father among them, isn't sure that Go-Man is on their side. Can Grace and Okidoki, Tobi's robot monkey friend, help restore Tobi's confidence and win over the Robug Squad?"Go-Man! Volume 1, Champion of Earth

events.title: Adult Book Club: Hum
events.description: Please join us for a discussion of Hum by Helen Phillips.In a city addled by climate change and populated by intelligent robots called 'hums,' May loses her job to artificial intelligence. In a desperate bid to resolve her family's debt and secure their future for another few months, she becomes a guinea pig in an experiment that alters her face so it cannot be recognized by surveillance. Seeking some reprieve from her recent hardships and from her family's addiction to their devices, she splurges on passes that allow them three nights' respite inside the Botanical Garden: a rare green refuge where forests, streams, and animals flourish. But her insistence that her son, daughter, and husband leave their devices at home proves far more fraught than she anticipated, and the lush beauty of the Botanical Garden is not the balm she hoped it would be.Place a hold or pick up a copy at the Avalon circulation desk. How to AttendThis event takes place in person. Questions about visiting the library? Check out our Using the Library FAQs. AccessibilityNeed sign language interpretation or other accessibility assistance for this event? Please call (312) 747-8184 or email access@chipublib.org to request accommodations. Requests must be made at least 14 business days before the event.

events.title: Black Women Directors presents: Free Angela and All Political Prisoners
events.description: In honor of Women's History Month, Black Women Directors and the Chicago Public Library present a free screening of Free Angela and All Political Prisoners, directed by Shola Lynch. This screening is presented by Black Women Directors, a digital archive and curatorial platform founded by Danielle A. Scruggs that celebrates the work of Black women and non-binary filmmakers worldwide. After the film, join us for a community conversation guided by Scruggs, Morgan Elise Johnson, filmmaker and publisher of The Triibe, an independent, Black-owned digital news publication and Block Club Chicago journalist Jamie Nesbitt Golden. Additionally, Dr. Eve L. Ewing and Build have donated 10 of Angela Davis's books to be given to the first 10 attendees so arrive early! For further reading: a booklist curated by the presenter. Accessibility Need sign language interpretation or other accessibility assistance for this event? Please call (312) 747-8184 or email access@chipublib.org to request accommodations. Requests must be made at least 14 business days before the event.Photo provided by presenter.
