events.title: Community Read:  Sing Loud and Proud
events.description: Join Charlotte's LGBTQIA+ non-auditioned One Voice Chorus for Sing Loud and Proud, a community-centered performance celebrating courage, identity, and belonging. Inspired by the themes of this year’s Community Read selection, The House in the Cerulean Sea by TJ Klune, the program features uplifting songs from pop, Broadway, and queer choral traditions. All ages are welcome, but please note that this performance contains mature themes. About Community Read Community Read is Charlotte Mecklenburg Library’s annual, community-wide book club—an invitation to connect through a shared story. Each year’s book selection inspires programs, community conversations, and events that explore timely and meaningful themes. This year’s title The House in the Cerulean Sea by TJ Klune explores themes of found family, belonging, and self-acceptance. Please join us at programs and events all month long and pick up your free copy at any Charlotte Mecklenburg Library location, while supplies last. Learn more at cmlibrary.org/community-read

events.title: Pineville Rainbow Reads Teen Book Club
events.description: This club meets monthly to discuss titles that feature LGBTQIA+ writers and characters. This program is provided by Pineville Library Staff and recommended for teens ages 14 to 18 and new adults 18-24. Information about this title:Jane Worthing's claim to fame is that she was one of the first viral internet sensations...discovered as a one-year-old in an oversized Gucci bag by her adopted father in a Poughkeepsie train station. Now in her senior year of high school, Janey is questioning whether she wants to look for her bio family due to a loving, but deeply misguided push from her best friend Algie, while also navigating an all-consuming crush on his cousin, the beautiful, way-out-of-her-league Gwen Fairfax.Looking for the book? Check out our catalog and place a hold:Book: Epically Earnest eBook: Epically Earnest How to Join an Online Program This event takes place on Zoom. You’ll receive an email with a link to the secure Zoom meeting with a confirmation email from staff. New to using Zoom? Check out these resources to help you get started.

events.title: Adv. 3D Printing for Youth
events.description: Ready to take your 3D design skills to the next level? Join us at Advanced 3D Printing for Youth! In this club, we’ll dive deeper into 3D modeling techniques, troubleshoot designs, and experiment with more advanced tools. Whether you want to create functional gadgets, detailed miniatures, or creative prints, this is your chance to push your understanding of 3D printing! EPL staff will provide guidance and feedback as you refine your designs! Each participant’s final design will be 3D printed for free and available for pickup at your local EPL branch. Recommended for ages 9-15 with prior experience in TinkerCAD or 3D design. If attendees want to create an object larger than 6cm x 6cm x 6cm, parents must complete the certification and bring a USB to the class so that the Makerspace can support with processing the print! To 3D print at the Makerspace: An adult (or youth aged 12+) must be certified to 3D print, which is a quick online process found on our website!Book the printer by calling 780-944-5342, email makerspace@epl.ca, or chat face to face with Makerspace staff!Slice the design in the Makerspace, in Children's library, in our class, or on your own devices!Bring the file on a USB to the Makerspace to process. Other branches with on-the-floor 3D printing services are: Abbottsfield, Mill Woods, and Capilano!

events.title: Queer Book Club
events.description: Each month, this book club will discuss books in a variety of genres, from fantasy to contemporary fiction, memoirs to graphic novels, and more! What these stories share in common is that they center authors or characters with queer identities. This club's main goal is to chat about books, but also provide a safe space for anyone in the LGBTQIAP+ community who deserve to see a version of themselves within the pages of a book. We also welcome allies wanting to expand their bookish horizons. We meet on the first Saturday of the month, with a couple exceptions due to holidays. For more info, including the club's reading list, go here or contact Adam at alopez@lplks.org

events.title: Text & Textiles
events.description: A book club for crafty people! Do you like to read? Do you also like to create textiles? Let's combine the two into a new (crafty) book club we call Text & Textiles! Here's how it works: Read any book you want. Audiobooks count, too!Make a granny square, quilt block, or other textile in the colors found on the cover of the book you read.Bring your finished textile to the meeting, and tell us about the book you read. Over time, you'll have enough granny squares or quilt blocks to make a larger finished project. This program takes place in The Spark and is for adults. Registration is not required, but space is limited to the first 15 people. (Note: this session repeats on December 6. The same information will be covered. There is no need to attend both.) Library staff may take photos, videos, or audio recordings at our events. Please tell us if you do not wish to be photographed, video-recorded, or audio-recorded. We will always respect your requests!An ASL (American Sign Language) interpreter or closed captioning can be provided for this program if requested at least 7 business days in advance. For assistance, please contact your library or accessibility@aclibrary.org.

events.title: Nonfiction Book Discussion: How to Change Your Mind by  Michael Pollan
events.description: Book Cover: How to Change Your Mind by Michael Pollan.Open to all adults who love to read and discuss Nonfictional literature. In March the book will be How to Change Your Mind: What the New Science of Psychedelics Teaches Us About Consciousness, Dying, Addiction, Depression, and Transcendence by Michael Pollan. (2018)Psychadelic drugs such as LSD and psilocybin earned a destructive and frightening reputation during the 1960’s, but Michael Pollan set out to research their more beneficial properties in treating depression, addiction and anxiety. Upon discovering how these remarkable substances are improving the lives not only of the mentally ill but also of healthy people coming to grips with the challenges of everyday life, Pollan decided to explore the landscape of the mind in the first person as well as the third. In this book, he sifts the historical record to separate the truth about these mysterious drugs from the myths that have surrounded them since the 1960s, when a handful of psychedelic evangelists catalyzed a powerful backlash against what was then a promising field of research. The Adult Nonfiction Book Discussion meets on the second Sunday of each month at 11am in Room 201B. All meetings are sponsored by The Friends of the Cupertino Library. For accessibility accommodations (ex. ASL), please fill out the online form at sccld.org/accessibility 7+days prior to the event. If you need assistance with the form, speak with a staff member at your local library, call (408) 540-3945, or email us at ask@sccl.org.

events.title: Castro Valley Reads Discussion Group
events.description: Join us for a discussion of the book selection for Castro Valley Reads! Our selection for 2026 is Advice for Future Corpses* (And those who love them) by Sallie Tisdale. From the sublime (the faint sound of Mozart as you take your last breath) to the ridiculous (lessons on how to close the sagging jaw of a corpse), Tisdale leads us through the peaks and troughs of death with a calm, wise, and humorous hand. Advice for Future Corpses is more than a how-to manual or a spiritual bible: it is a graceful compilation of honest and intimate anecdotes based on the deaths Tisdale has witnessed in her work and life, as well as stories from cultures, traditions, and literature around the world. Free copies of the book are available while supplies last. The free copies will be distributed beginning Sunday, February 1, at 2 pm at the CV Reads Kick-Off Event. The book is also available in the Library collection. Advice for Future Corpses* An ASL (American Sign Language) interpreter or closed captioning can be provided for this program if requested at least seven (7) days in advance. For assistance, please contact your library or accessibility@aclibrary.org.

Meeting datesJanuary 12, 26 (No class Jan 19)February 2, 23 (No class Feb 9, 16)March 2, 9, 23, 30 (No class Mar 16)April 13, 20, 27 (No class Apr 6)Meeting time: 10:15am - 11:45amWhere: In the library - your book club leader will tell you which tables. Registration is open now! Book club is limited to 10 participants. Books will be provided for registered participants to keep. Please consider your schedule and do not register if you will miss more than one meeting. The Murderbot Diaries Vol 1 description:On a distant planet, a team of scientists are conducting surface tests, shadowed by their Company-supplied ‘droid ― a self-aware SecUnit that has hacked its own governor module, and refers to itself (though never out loud) as “Murderbot.” Scornful of humans, all it really wants is to be left alone long enough to figure out who it is (and to watch its favorite show in its downtime.) But when a neighboring mission goes dark, it’s up to the scientists and Murderbot to get to the truth.

events.title: Community Read: How to Talk to Your Neighbors
events.description: Do you know the names of the neighborhood dogs but not their human companions? Have you been wanting to ask your neighbor how they keep their garden alive but don’t know how to start the conversation? Do you want to create change but don't know where to start? This is an interactive program to help us get connected, to think about our neighbors and our neighborhoods, how we fit in, how we stand out, how we keep to ourselves, how we come out of our shells and what we can do to make our own small bit of the world a better place. Join us for an evening of light refreshments, conversation, and practice. The US Surgeon General reports that the United States currently has an epidemic of loneliness and isolation. This has a heavy impact on personal health and on communal prosperity. It impacts our democracy, our divisions, and our resilience to hardship. Come hear from two neighbors about how simple connections can improve our own lives and also build resilient supportive communities. Let’s create a collective vision for safety, care, and mutual aid—one neighborly conversation at a time. Whether you’re already building relationships in your neighborhood or feel like you’d like to start, this event is for anyone who wants to strengthen community ties. This program is provided by community presenters Sam Poler and Jada Daire McGirt. About Community ReadCommunity Read is Charlotte Mecklenburg Library’s annual, community-wide book club—an invitation to connect through a shared story. Each year’s book selection inspires programs, community conversations, and events that explore timely and meaningful themes. This year’s title The House in the Cerulean Sea by TJ Klune explores themes of found family, belonging, and self-acceptance. Please join us at programs and events all month long and pick up your free copy at any Charlotte Mecklenburg Library location, while supplies last. Learn more at cmlibrary.org/community-read.

events.title: Book Bites Book Club
events.description: Have a new snack while we discuss our book every 3rd Monday of the month. After, you keep the book! Grades 3-5, reg. req — This month's book will be Rump by Liesl Shurtliff! Don't forget to grab your copy from the children's desk. In a magic kingdom where your name is your destiny, 12-year-old Rump is the butt of everyone's joke. But when he finds an old spinning wheel, his luck seems to change. Rump discovers he has a gift for spinning straw into gold. His best friend, Red Riding Hood, warns him that magic is dangerous, and she's right. With each thread he spins, he weaves himself deeper into a curse. To break the spell, Rump must go on a perilous quest, fighting off pixies, trolls, poison apples, and a wickedly foolish queen. The odds are against him, but with courage and friendship-and a cheeky sense of humor-he just might triumph in the end. A Texas Bluebonnet finalist and winner of the ILA award for middle grade fiction, Rump is perfect for fans of Gail Carson Levine's Ella Enchanted or Adam Gidwitz's A Tale Dark and Grimm.

events.title: True Crime Podcast Discussion Club
events.description: Do you love true crime? Join us for a true crime podcast discussion club! Twice a month, we’ll meet virtually to discuss a few episodes of a true crime podcast, share our favorites, and get recommendations. Over the next few weeks, we'll be listening to Can I Tell You a Secret?, a series from The Guardian about cyberstalker Matthew Hardy and his web of deception. You can listen via the link above or on Apple or Spotify. Here's what to listen to before we meet: March 9: Episode 1 "The Beginning" and 2 "The Widening Circle"March 23: Episode 3 "The Man Upstairs" and 4 "A Reckoning"April 6: Episode 5 "A Mother's Love," 6 "The Winding Clock" and 7 "An Update" This program is for adults 18 and up due to mature themes, violence, and adult language that may be in the podcasts. These podcasts may contain triggering themes and may feature content warnings. Spoiler prevention: If you listen to episodes beyond the week's assigned episodes, please do not reveal details during our discussion to prevent spoilers! This program will be provided by North County and Matthews library staff. How to Join an Online Program This event takes place on Zoom. Please register by 5:00 p.m. the day before the event. events.description: A book club dedicated to "Journey to the West," the classic Chinese fiction. This club is designed for children who are fans of the story and is conducted entirely in Mandarin Chinese. The event is organized by dedicated teen volunteers from Lynbrook High School.小朋友们，你们听说过《西游记》吗？ 这是中国最有名的神话故事之一，讲述了一段惊险又有趣的旅程。在这个故事里，有聪明勇敢的孙悟空、善良慈悲的唐僧、憨厚搞笑的猪八戒，还有忠诚可靠的沙和尚。他们一路上经历了许多危险和考验，但靠着智慧和团结，成功完成了任务。这次旅程不仅是他们追寻经书的故事，更是一场关于勇气、坚持和成长的冒险！更多有关 美猴王系列丛书. 免费的亲子中文活動. 座位数量有限. 门票将在故事时间开始前 30 分钟在询问处领取。 圖書館中文资源: 大人最新中文书, 中文電子書, 非小說類電子書 (Overdrive) 有歡迎大家一起來借閱電子書. Overdirve平台: 小朋友的中文電子書, 大朋友的中文電子小說, 大朋友的非小說類的電子書籍. Hoopla平台: 中文有聲書籍 美国残疾人法案(ADA)申请提供协助 5/25/2026

events.title: 2nd Mondays Adult Manga & Manhwa Club
events.description: Do you love manga/manhwa or have you always wanted to try it out? Want other adults to discuss books with? Now is your chance! You can register and pick up a copy of the book from the Reference desk. Please bring your Alameda County Library Card to the meeting to check out next month's book. Library staff may take photos, videos, or audio recordings at our events. Please tell us if you do not wish to be photographed, video-recorded, or audio-recorded. events.title: SciFi & Fantasy Book Club
events.description: Do you love delving into mysterious and fantastical worlds? Are intricate magic systems and complex alien civilizations your thing? Or are you in it for characters and themes not so different from our own lives, sorcery or space life notwithstanding? If so, then join our Science Fiction and Fantasy Book Club at San Mateo County Libraries! We'll meet every second Monday of the month at 6:30 PM at the Foster City Library. Want to know what we're reading? Click the registration link below to view an up-to-date reading list as well as our past titles. REGISTER HERE

events.title: Lynnwood Library Book Group - "The Women" by Kristin Hannah
events.description: Join us to celebrate the love of reading with others in our community! This month's selection is The Women by Kristin Hannah. In 1965, nursing student Frankie McGrath, after hearing the words "Women can be heroes, too," impulsively joins the Army Nurse Corps and follows her brother to Vietnam where she is overwhelmed by the destruction of war, as well as the unexpected trauma of coming home to a changed and politically divided America.Visit the following link to view all of Lynnwood Library Book Group's 2026 selections: Lynnwood Library Book Club 2026 Titles. Books are selected by members of the group and cover a variety of genres. The Lynnwood Library Book Group meets regularly on the second Monday of each month from 6:30-7:45pm. Contact us with questions Programs & Events FAQs To request a sign language interpreter, complete this online form or contact your local library at least two weeks prior to the library event. Interpreters will be provided based on availability.

events.title: Science Fiction and Fantasy Book Club - Solaris by Stanislaw Lem
events.description: Explore strange new worlds and alternate realities by joining the Science Fiction and Fantasy Book Club at Milpitas Library! Sign up and pick up a copy of Solaris by Stanislaw Lem . Read it and meet us on Monday, March 9th at 7pm in the Auditorium of Milpitas Library. "What happens when we encounter something we can never truly understand?" On a distant planet orbiting a strange sun lies an endless, sentient ocean—a living enigma that defies explanation. When psychologist Kris Kelvin arrives at the Solaris Station, he finds a crew on the brink of madness and begins confronting mysteries that are both alien and deeply personal. A haunting exploration of humanity’s limits in the face of the unknown, Solaris is a masterpiece of philosophical science fiction that will leave you questioning the boundaries of knowledge, memory, and meaning. Can we ever truly communicate with the other—or are we destined to see only ourselves? For accessibility accommodations (ex. ASL), please fill out the online form at sccld.org/accessibility 7+days prior to the event. If you need assistance with the form, speak with a staff member at your local library, call (408) 540-3945, or email us at ask@lib.sccgov.org

events.title: StoryWalk® with Dougherty Station and San Ramon Libraries
events.description: Get some exercise and read the latest story installed at the StoryWalk in Central Park. The winter themed story is called Except Antarctica, written and illustrated by Todd Sturgell. Follow turtle and learn about animals found on every continent except Antarctica!The San Ramon StoryWalk® is a permanent feature in San Ramon’s Central Park. The 20-station project features a new book four times a year. The San Ramon StoryWalk® project is a partnership with the Rotary Club of San Ramon, the City of San Ramon, the San Ramon Library Foundation, and the Library. The Central Park StoryWalk® begins near the Alcosta parking lot to the right of the playground, ending at the Community Center’s rear fountain. The StoryWalk Project was created by Anne Ferguson of Montpelier, VT and developed in collaboration with the Kellogg-Hubbard Library. StoryWalk is a registered service mark owned by Ms. Ferguson.

events.title: Historic Xenia REVEALED
events.description: Did Helen Hooven Santmyer reveal the real Xenia in …And Ladies of the Club? Let’s find out! --- Come and listen to Catherine Wilson as she tells us about the real Xenia revealed in Helen Hooven Santmyer’s book …And Ladies of the Club. Find out what places in the fictional Waynesboro were places that Santmyer knew in Xenia. Catherine has served as Executive Director of the Greene County Historical Society since 2008. She has written and presented on local history topics and published the book Historic Greene County: An Illustrated History (2010).

events.title: Between The Panels: Tween Graphic Novel Book Club
events.description: Calling all tweens? Do you enjoy reading? Are you looking for people to talk about what you’ve just read? Are you down for some book related activities? If your answer is yes to all of the above, sign up for our tween book club to join us for a lively discussion along with a fun activity. This program is for ages 9-12. Registration is required. We will meet in-person in the Spring Branch Memorial Library Meeting Room. Once registered, you will be contacted when a copy of the book is available for pick up. The book we will be reading: Plain Jane and the Mermaid by Vera Brosgol. Jane is incredibly plain. Everyone says so: her parents, the villagers, and her horrible cousin who kicks her out of her own house. Determined to get some semblance of independence, Jane prepares to propose to the princely Peter. It's a good plan!Or it would've been, if he wasn't kidnapped by a mermaid. Jane must venture underwater to rescue her maybe-fiancé. But the depths of the ocean hold beautiful mysteries and dangerous creatures. What good can a plain Jane do?

events.title: Bookmarked Book Club
events.description: This month’s selection is Finding Me by Viola Davis. This book is Viola Davis' story, in her own words, and spans her incredible, inspiring life, from her coming-of-age in Rhode Island to her present day. Hers is a story of overcoming, a true hero's journey. Deeply personal, brutally honest, and riveting, Finding Me is a timeless and spellbinding memoir that will capture hearts and minds around the globe.Finding Me

events.title: Book Clubs of EPL: The Anthropocene Reviewed
events.description: Love reading? Love to talk about books you've read? Join our book club for spirited discussions on a wide range of fiction and non-fiction. Each month we'll tackle a new title. Whether you loved it, loathed it, or left it unfinished, we want to hear your take. Come share your impressions and connect with fellow readers! This week we will be reading The Anthropocene Reviewed by John Green."The Anthropocene is the current geological age, in which human activity has profoundly shaped the planet and its biodiversity. In this remarkable symphony of essays adapted and expanded from his groundbreaking podcast, John Green reviews different facets of the human-centered planet-from the QWERTY keyboard and Staphylococcus aureus to the Taco Bell breakfast menu-on a five-star scale. John Green's gift for storytelling shines throughout this artfully curated collection that includes both beloved essays and all-new pieces exclusive to the book"--Provided by publisher.

events.title: The Page Turners
events.description: The Page Turners is an evening book discussion group for adults that meets at the Castro Valley Library on the second Tuesday of the month at 7 pm. Facilitated by librarian Chris Selig, the discussions focus on compelling, well-reviewed fiction and nonfiction books written for adults.For March we will discuss the Castro Valley Reads book selection for 2026, Advice for Future Corpses (and Those Who Love Them) by Sallie Tisdale. Tisdale's book isn't built on a conventional plot; instead, it unfolds as a clear-eyed, compassionate exploration of something universal yet often avoided: dying. Drawing from her long experience as a palliative-care nurse, she guides readers through the practical, emotional, and spiritual realities of the end of life. What emerges is not a manual of dread, but an invitation to look directly at mortality with honesty and even tenderness. The magic of this book lies in Tisdale's voice. She moves with ease between intimate stories from the bedside, philosophical reflections, and grounded, often surprising advice. As she explores the fears, confusions, hopes, and small graces that accompany dying, she reveals the complex inner landscapes of patients, caregivers, and loved ones alike. Her writing is at once candid, lyrical, funny, and deeply humane. Through these interwoven perspectives, we're offered not just practical wisdom but a rare kind of companionship on a topic many of us struggle to face. Ultimately, Advice for Future Corpses is about how to meet mortality—with clarity, courage, humility, and love—and, in doing so, how to live more fully.Advice for Future Corpses* and Those Who Love Them _________ An ASL (American Sign Language) interpreter can be provided for this program if requested at least seven business days in advance. For assistance, please contact your library or accessibility@aclibrary.org.

events.title: Wednesday Afternoon Murder Mystery Book Club: Jar of Hearts
events.description: Are you a reader looking for a murder mystery to solve, a thrill to seek, or a story full of suspense? If you answer yes to any or all these questions, you must join Edgebrook Branch's Wednesday Afternoon Murder Mystery Book Club! For March, we are reading and discussing Jar of Hearts by Jennifer Hillier. "Angela was one of the most popular girls in her high school before she disappeared without a trace. Nobody ever knew what became of her—not Georgina, her best friend, nor Kaiser, who was close with both girls. Then, fourteen years later, Angela’s remains were discovered in the woods near Geo’s childhood home and Kaiser—who became a detective with the Seattle police department—finally learned the truth: Angela was a victim of Calvin James. To the authorities, Calvin was a notorious serial killer. But back in the day, Calvin was Geo’s first love. Their relationship bordered on obsession from the moment they met, right up until the night Angela was killed. Geo carried the secret of Calvin’s dark deeds until the evidence landed her in prison. But now, just as Geo is about to be released, new bodies start turning up—killed in the exact same manner as Angela...and soon Geo, Kaiser, and local law enforcement officials realize that what happened that fateful night is more complex and chilling than anyone could have imagined." - Description from MacMillan Publishers. Copies of the book will be available at Edgebrook Branch's reference desk starting on 3/12/26 while supplies last. AccessibilityNeed sign language interpretation or other accessibility assistance for this event? Please call (312) 747-8184 or email access@chipublib.org to request accommodations. Requests must be made at least 14 business days before the event.

events.title: Book Club for Tweens!
events.description: East Point Library is excited to launch its first tween book club! Join us as we launch our very first Tween Book Club! Starting now, tweens ages 8-13 are invited to check out our first book selection: "Pippa Park Raises Her Game" by Erin Yun. At Lakeview, Pippa juggles old and new friends, an unrequited crush, and the pressure to perform academically and athletically while keeping her past and her family's laundromat a secret from her elite new classmates—a fun, feel-good story about friendship, basketball, and finding your confidence. The East Point Library has copies available in paperback, or you can check out this book as a downloadable audiobook and an eBook. Whether you love to read, want to make new friends, or are looking for a fun after-school activity, our Tween Book Club is a great way to connect with other book lovers and discover new stories together. Mark your calendars—our very first book club get-together is happening on March 11h at 4:00 pm! I can’t wait to chat about this book with you!

events.title: Virtual Next Chapter Book Club: Top Story
events.description: You're invited to join the Saint Paul Public Library's Next Chapter Book Club as we read Top Story by Kelly Yang. Since the fall of 2016, Saint Paul Public Library has been a Next Chapter Book Club affiliate. Next Chapter Book Club offers community-based book clubs for adolescents and adults with intellectual and developmental disabilities. Our members (including some who cannot read) love the way books transport them to different worlds where they meet interesting characters and learn about exciting new things. Taking that journey with a group of friends makes it even more delightful and fun. Join us online (click this link to connect to the virtual book club) Wednesdays 5-6 pm until we reach the end of the book. Estimated end date in March. Contact Erin at erin.zolotukhin-ridgway@ci.stpaul.mn.us with questions. This book will be shared online during book club.

events.title: Fantasy and Science Fiction Book Club: Iron Gold by Pierce Brown
events.description: Join us on the second Wednesday each month to discuss a fantasy or science fiction book! --- This month's title is Iron Gold by Pierce Brown.A decade ago, Darrow was the hero of the revolution he believed would break the chains of the Society, and abolish the color-coded caste system. But the Rising has shattered everything, and brought endless war. New foes emerge to threaten what has been earned, and throughout the worlds other destinies entwine with Darrow's to change his fate forever. A young Red girl flees tragedy in her refugee camp, and achieves for herself a new life she could never have imagined. An ex-soldier broken by grief is forced to steal the most valuable thing in the galaxy -- or pay with his life. And Lysander au Lune, the heir in exile to the Sovereign, wanders the stars with his mentor, Cassius, haunted by the loss of the world that Darrow transformed, and dreaming of what will rise from its ashes.

events.title: Spectacular Sixth Grade Book Club
events.description: Spectacular Sixth Grade Book Club is a book discussion group for 6th graders. If you love reading books and discussing them with a group, this is the place for you! Some months we'll also have an activity to go along with the discussion. We'll meet on the second Wednesday of the month. This month, we are reading Alone by Megan E. Freeman. events.title: Dayton's Bluff Book Club
events.description: Dayton's Bluff Book Club is a great fit for folks who love reading diverse books by local authors and discussing them with a group of dedicated readers. We meet once a month on a Wednesday in the months of October, November, December, February, March, and April at 6 p.m. We have a limited supply of free books for book club participants that will be available for pick up at the Dayton's Bluff Branch Library when selections become finalized. Participants will be notified by email. Books will also be available to borrow at the library. The Dayton’s Bluff Book Club is a collaboration of the Metropolitan State University Library and the Dayton’s Bluff Branch of Saint Paul Public Library whose members live, work or attend classes on the East Side. We prioritize our selection of titles to those written by Minnesota authors, that have a local setting, or that are written by people of color and other diverse authors. Book discussions usually include issues related to social justice, equity, and anti-racism. We encourage book club members to use both the university and public libraries in pursuit of lifelong learning and the joy of reading. Discussions are frequently facilitated by authors, Metropolitan State faculty, or other guests from the community. Where They Last Saw HerWelcome - Dayton's Bluff Book Club - LibGuides at Metropolitan State University

events.title: Jewish American Fiction Book Club: The Last Dekrepitzer
events.description: Everyone is welcome to join our online (Zoom) book discussion group on Wednesday March 11, 2026. For more information and a Zoom invite, contact Davo Knepler at nuevodavos@yahoo.com.We will be discussing The Last Dekrepitzer by Howard Langer. The author will be joining us for the discussion. WINNER NATIONAL JEWISH BOOK AWARD The fiddler busking in the Columbus Circle subway station in 1965 is the Dekrepitzer Rebbe, the sole survivor of the obscure Dekrepitzer Hasidic sect known before the war for its rebbes' fiddling. The Last Dekrepitzer follows the life and spiritual quest of Shmuel Meir Lichtbencher a/k/a Sam Lightup, from his isolated shtetl in the mountains of southern Poland, where he is brought up to be the future rebbe, to the wharves in Naples, where he jams with Black soldiers waiting to ship home at the end of the war. Dressing him in the uniform and dog tags of an AWOL soldier, they smuggle him home to rural Mississippi. He lives for years among the Blacks, speaks Black English, preaches and plays the blues with the Brown Sugar Ramblers trio. His marriage to a Black woman, Lula Curtin, legal by Jewish law though forbidden under Mississippi law, results in a cross burning that forces them to flee to Manhattan. He plays on the streets of Harlem and Midtown with the Reverend Gary Davis, the great blind guitarist whose mission is saving souls for the next world. Shmuel Meir's devout wife, though she knows herself to be the Dekrepitzer Rebbitzen, is spurned by the Jewish community. Through it all, Shmuel Meir fiddles his prayers in defiance of God. But God gives the Dekrepitzer Rebbe no peace.For more information and a Zoom invite, contact Davo Knepler at nuevodavos@yahoo.com. Everyone is welcome to attend. Sponsored by Gan HaLev-the Jewish Congregation of San Geronimo Valley and the Fairfax Library, and assisted by the Jewish Library of San Francisco ADA Accommodation Request | Solicitud de Adaptación ADA

events.title: Getting Cozy Book Club
events.description: If you've never read a cozy mystery before or if you have read thousands, join us each month as we read and discuss the first book in a series. We will meet on the 2nd Thursday of the month at 10 am. What is a cozy mystery? The crime-solver is an amateur sleuth, who eavesdrops, gathers clues, and uses their native intelligence and knowledge of their community to solve the crime. Cozy mysteries are generally considered “gentle” books and most have no graphic violence. The setting is often a small town full of colorful characters.Series frequently have a prominent thematic element introduced by the detective's job, pet, or hobby.These books are plot and character driven with an emphasis on solving puzzles rather than suspense. Our chosen book with serve as our theme for the meeting, we will talk about other book series with a similar theme as well as the recipes, crafts, and more included in many cozies.

Be ready to read your favorite passages to the group! If the books on this list look too easy, try our Advanced ESL Book Club. events.title: Intermediate ESL Book Club - Chains (The Seeds of America Trilogy)
events.description: Our intermediate ESL Book Club will read Chains (The Seeds of America Trilogy) by Laurie Halse Anderson. This book club is best for intermediate English learners. Students will read at home each week. Then we will meet as a group once a week to talk about the story, learn new vocabulary, and practice conversation. Book club will be led by Roberta Linsky. Meeting dates: February 26; March 5, 12, 19; April 2, 16; May 7. (No class March 26; April 9, 23, 30.)Meeting time: Thursdays from 10:00am - 11:00amWhere: Tables by the wall posters Registration is open now! Book club is limited to 10 participants. Books will be provided for registered participants to keep. Please consider your schedule and do not register if you will miss more than one meeting. Book description:As the Revolutionary War begins, thirteen-year-old Isabel wages her own fight...for freedom. Promised freedom upon the death of their owner, she and her sister, Ruth, in a cruel twist of fate become the property of a malicious New York City couple, the Locktons, who have no sympathy for the American Revolution and even less for Ruth and Isabel. When Isabel meets Curzon, a slave with ties to the Patriots, he encourages her to spy on her owners, who know details of British plans for invasion. She is reluctant at first, but when the unthinkable happens to Ruth, Isabel realizes her loyalty belongs to whoever can provide her with freedom.

events.title: Civic Center Morning Mystery Book Group: 'Death of a Liar' by M.C. Beaton
events.description: The Civic Center Library's Morning Mystery Book Group will meet on Thursday, February 12th from 11:00am-12:00pm to discuss Death of a Liar by M.C. Beaton. This mystery book group generally meets on the 2nd Thursday of every month from 11:00-12:00n. All are welcome to join! Request a copy of the book online or ask at the Info Desk of the Civic Center Library (or call 415-473-6057) for assistance in placing a hold. Death of A Liar (book) or Death of A Liar (large print book) by M.C. Beaton Book #30 in the series set in a fictional town in the Scottish Highlands featuring police constable Hamish Macbeh. Sergeant Hamish Macbeth is alarmed to receive a report from a woman in the small village of Cronish in the Scottish Highlands. She has been brutally attacked and the criminal is on the loose. But upon further investigation, Hamish discovers that she was lying about the crime. So when the same woman calls him back about an intruder, he simply marvels at her compulsion to lie. This time, though, she is telling the truth. Her body is found in her home and Hamish must sort through all of her lies to solve the crime. - adapted from the publisher ADA Accommodation Request | Solicitud de Adaptación ADA

events.title: Book Clubs of EPL - On Book Banning
events.description: Love reading? Love to talk about books you've read? Come join us for lively discussions on all types of fiction and non-fiction. We'll feature different titles and authors each month. Join us to share your impressions, thoughts and interpretations of a book we have all read. "On Book Banning" by Ira Wells SYNOPSIS: From the destruction of libraries in ancient Rome to today’s state-sponsored efforts to suppress LGBTQ+ literature, book bans arise from the impulse toward social control. In a survey of legal cases, literary controversies, and philosophical arguments, Ira Wells illustrates the historical opposition to the freedom to read and argues that today’s conservatives and progressives alike are warping our children’s relationship with literature and teaching them that the solution to opposing viewpoints is outright expurgation. At a moment in which our democratic institutions are buckling under the stress of polarization, On Book Banning is both rallying cry and guide to resistance for those who will always insist upon reading for themselves.

events.title: March Moraga Book Club
events.description: Join other book lovers for a lively discussion regarding Ruth Reichl's The Paris Novel:Stella, estranged from her mother Celia, inherits money for a trip to Paris. Reluctantly, she goes and lives modestly while visiting attractions. An impulse purchase of a vintage Dior dress leads her to meet Jules, an art expert who expands her horizons. This multi-layered narrative appeals to fans of art, culture, Paris and happy endings. Ruth Reichl is the New York Times bestselling author of five memoirs. She was editor in chief of Gourmet magazine, and previously served as restaurant critic for The New York Times, as well as food editor and restaurant critic for the Los Angeles Times.Note that Moraga Book Club is for adults ages 18 and up. It is also an in-person event at Moraga Library and online (through Zoom). Registration is required for online participation only.

events.title: Mystery Book Club
events.description: Do you relish unraveling riddles, decoding secrets, and solving whodunits? Then join the Belmont Mystery Book Club where suspense, intrigue, and thrilling twists are something you can count on!Each month, we delve into a gripping mystery novel, meet to discuss theories, dissect clues, and share our guesses all while enjoying lively conversation with fellow detectives at heart.Expect laughter, lively debate, and maybe even a few “aha!” moments as we explore the mysteries on our shelves. You bring the sleuthing spirit; we’ll bring the enigmatic ambiance! This month’s mystery awaits. Will you crack the case with us? Reach out by email to be added to the mailing list for notices and book club updates.

events.title: BeTWEEN The Lines Book Club: I Survived Edition
events.description: Read books at home, and then explore them together with fun crafts and projects! 3/12: I Survived the Shark Attacks of 1916 4/9: I Survived the Great Alaska Earthquake, 1964 DML welcomes everyone to our programs. If you have questions or need any accommodations, please contact us so we can help make the program a good experience for you. Check out what you can expect when visiting the Huber Heights branch here!

events.title: Black History Club
events.description: Are you a Differencemaker or a Changemaker? Having trouble deciding? We have the perfect club for youBLACK HISTORY CLUB!

events.title: Book Lovers Crochet Club
events.description: It's a crochet club with a twist! Want to learn to crochet or need a little motivation to finish your project? Join us as we crochet together and listen to an audiobook while crafting. Bring some friends to enjoy both the story and the company! All skill levels are welcome, from ages 8 to adult. Supplies and patterns will be provided, but feel free to bring your own. Registration helps us to plan the event, but walk-ins are always welcome! Support staff are also welcome. Please contact us if accommodations are needed.

events.title: Inspirational Book Club
events.description: Join us on 2nd Tuesdays for the Inspirational Book Club, a self-run club of readers! If you enjoy "lighter" reads with a positive message, this is the book club for you! Some copies are available downstairs at the Reference Desk, but each member is responsible for obtaining their own copy. Please check out our catalog to request a book!

events.title: Book Buddies (Ages 5-8)
events.description: Books are friends! Join us to celebrate our favorite book characters. Play book-related games, create book character art and discover similar reads. You do not have to have read the book to enjoy this program! This month: Witchycakes. This program is designed for kids (ages 5-8) based on the skills we'll be practicing or the tools used. Offering age-appropriate programming allows us to craft memorable and personalized experiences for all our patrons, no matter their age.Manage your event registration through "My Events" when signed in to a library account. DISCOVER MORE Running of out books to read? Ask a librarian for even more personalized recommendations!Visit the Kids Page to discover additional recommendations and resources.

events.title: Teen Comic Book Club
events.description: Comics, Manga, Graphic Novels, and more!! If you like comics, this club is for you. Bring whatever you’ve been reading lately and make a comic of your own. All comics are welcome. Graphic novels, super hero comics, manga, webcomics, manwha -- we read it all! We'll discuss the best stuff there is to read and learn about new skills for making comics. Get recommendations from teens who read what you read and recommend some of your own. Art supplies will be provided.

events.title: Next Chapter Book Club
events.description: Promoting literacy, social connections, and inclusion for adults with special needs. Registration is required. --- Next Chapter Book Club is for ages 18+ who have intellectual and developmental disabilities. It’s a community-based book club that promotes literacy, social connections, and inclusion for adults with special needs. Members read a book together and all levels of reading are able to participate. Meetings are facilitated by Greene County Board of Developmental Disabilities staff and Xenia Community Library staff. Registration is required.

book.title: together and all levels of reading are able to participate. Meetings are facilitated
book.author: Greene County Board of Developmental Disabilities staff and Xenia Community Library staff.

events.title: American Girl Book Club- Kit Kittredge
events.description: Join us to discuss the time period and books of this month’s American Girl! Gr. 3-6; Registration required. --- We will discuss the history of the featured doll’s time period and talk about what may have been like! Participants are encouraged to read or listen to the first book in the girl’s story (this month Read All About It!) to be able to join in on the discussion. Each month we will play games, do a craft, and have a light snack inspired by each girl’s life. In order to help everyone feel included, we kindly ask that you leave your personal dolls at home! Thank you!

events.title: Pages N' Popcorn at Barbara Bush
events.description: Join our Tween Book Club here at the Barbara Bush Branch Library! We will discuss a new book every month paired with a fun activity. The book for March will be The Storm Keeper's Island by Catherine Doyle. Popcorn is, of course, provided! You may bring you own snacks too. The registration form can be found here. This book club is for children ages 8-12. We meet twice a month. We will discuss the first half of the book at the first meeting of the month and discuss the rest of the book at the end of the month.Registration is required as copies are limited. You may obtain a copy in the Children's Department at the Barbara Bush Branch Library. You can also place a hold to pick up at your own convenience from the hcpl.net website.

events.title: Read It and Eat! Teen Book Club
events.description: Teen Book Club has transformed into Read It and Eat! It's a book club with a twist--during book club, you create something yummy based on this month's theme and then feast. This month, the theme is Girl Power and in honor of the founding of the Girl Scouts on this day in 1912, we will be doing a Girl Scout Cookie taste test. Readers of manga, graphic novels, books, and audiobooks are welcome! Even if you haven't read anything new lately, you can still join us! This program is for readers ages 13-18.

events.title: Silent Book Club
events.description: Put down your phone, pick up a book and spend quality time with fellow book lovers. This isn't your typical book club; there is no assigned reading or deadlines. Simply bring what you're reading and connect over a beverage.

events.title: Booktok Book Club
events.library: Public Library of Youngstown and Mahoning County
events.description: Do you find yourself adding tons of books to your TBR that you see becoming popular on social media but don't know where to start? Then join us for Booktok Book Club, where we will be reading all those buzzworthy and 'must-read' books that have become popular sensations on social media platforms. We'll talk about the book and the content that has stemmed from it online in a relaxed, casual atmosphere. The book for this session is Lights Out by Navessa Allen.

events.title: Widely Read Book Club
events.description: Interested in finding new books to love, expanding your reading horizons, and having friendly discussions with others about what you read? Join us for Widely Read, a book club that dives into a different genre in fiction or nonfiction every month! Loved it? Hated it? Didn't finish? Come and tell us why! March's book is The Fox Wife by Yangsze Choo. We will have physical copies at Kettering Moraine available for check out, though you can also find copies through our library catalog or on Libby.

events.title: Humanities Book Club: Farah Karim-Cooper
events.description: The Hall Center will provide a limited number of free copies of The Great White Bard to be read prior to the event by those who wish to attend and participate in the discussion. Interested participants should stop by the Hall Center or email pkenn@lplks.org while supplies last. An interdisciplinary panel of speakers will lead the discussion. As monuments of white Western history fall, many are asking: how is Shakespeare still relevant? In The Great White Bard: How to Love Shakespeare While Talking About Race, Farah Karim-Cooper acknowledges how the playwright has come to occupy such an elevated place in the Western canon, and what is lost when he is treated as representative of only one tradition or one group. Karim-Cooper examines race in Shakespeare’s plays through close readings of works such as Antony and Cleopatra and The Tempest, alongside a reappraisal of Elizabethan London and its social world. She argues that Shakespeare should neither be idealized nor discarded, but read with attention to the discomforts in his language and theatrical culture. As The New York Times writes, “The Great White Bard contributes to an essential discussion on Shakespeare and race.” By opening the plays to new perspectives, the book makes space for debate and reInterpretation, and for a Shakespeare who can still speak to the present. Farah Karim-Cooper is the Director of the Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington, D.C. and a leading scholar of race and performance in early modern drama. The Great White Bard: Shakespeare, Race and the Future was named one of the best books of the year by Time, NPR, The New Yorker, Kirkus Reviews, and Publishers Weekly.

events.title: Between the Bookends Book Club
events.library: Public Library of Youngstown and Mahoning County
events.description: We've all experienced a bit of burnout. Well, Sasha has had it. She's done with inane emails that aren't urgent and being part of the joyfulness employee program. She hasn't had a fun day, a day for herself in who knows how long. Follow Sasha in The Burnout by Sophia Kinsella as she works her way through it.

events.title: Read the World: A Middle Grade Book Club
events.description: Read the World is a book discussion group for youth in 6th to 9th grade. Each month we'll read a book set in a different country then enjoy conversations about the book as well as other cultures and experiences. We'll read from multiple categories, including fiction, nonfiction, graphic novels, novels in verse, and more. This month we'll be reading and discussing Temple Alley Summer by Sachiko Kashiwaba and set in Japan. Please register then stop by the library for a free copy of the book no earlier than one month before the discussion.One rainy night, Kazu sees a strange figure in a white kimono sneak out of his house--was he dreaming? Did he see a ghost? The next day at school, the very same person is sitting in his class--and all his friends are convinced that the ghost-girl Akari has been their friend for years. If that isn't weird enough, Kazu learns that his house is in the exact location of an ancient temple called Kimyō, which, legend has it, could bring the dead back to life! Kazu sets out to discover what happened to Kimyō Temple and if the rumors of its power are true. His investigation draws the unwanted attention of his neighbor Ms. Minakami and his mysterious new classmate Akari, who is definitely not what she seems. Now, Kazu and Akari must join forces to find and protect the source of the temple's power, before it's too late. Temple Alley Summer An ASL (American Sign Language) interpreter can be provided for this program if requested at least seven (7) business days in advance. For assistance, please contact your library or accessibility@aclibrary.org.

events.title: Book Portals and Journeys of Literary Magic with Kate Quinn
events.description: You’re invited to join us for a virtual conversation with acclaimed author Kate Quinn about her latest fantastical work, The Astral Library, which poses the question: Have you ever wished you could live inside a book? Welcome to the Astral Library, where books are not just objects, but doors to new worlds, new lives, and new futures. There is no need to register here but please do register at our partner site. Alexandria “Alix” Watson has learned one lesson from her barren childhood in the foster-care system: unlike people, books will never let you down. Working three dead-end jobs to make ends meet and knowing college is a pipe dream, Alix takes nightly refuge in the high-vaulted reading room at the Boston Public Library, escaping into her favorite fantasy novels and dreaming of far-off lands. Until the day she stumbles through a hidden door and meets the Librarian: the ageless, acerbic guardian of a hidden library where the desperate and the lost escape to new lives...inside their favorite books. The Librarian takes a dazzled Alix under her wing, but before she can escape into the pages of her new life, a shadowy enemy emerges to threaten everyone the Astral Library has ever helped protect. Aided by a dashing costume-shop owner, Alix and the Librarian flee through the Regency drawing rooms of Jane Austen to the back alleys of Sherlock Holmes and the champagne-soaked parties of The Great Gatsby as danger draws inexorably closer. But who does their enemy really wish to destroy—Alix, the Librarian, or the Library itself? Register now to hear more about The Astral Library, crafted for all bookworms and lovers of literature. About the Author: Kate Quinn is the New York Times and USA Today bestselling author of historical fiction. A native of Southern California, she attended Boston University, where she earned bachelor’s and master’s degrees in classical voice. A lifelong history buff, she has written four novels in the Empress of Rome Saga and two books set in the Italian Renaissance before turning to the 20th century with The Alice Network, The Huntress, The Rose Code, The Diamond Eye, and The Briar Club. The Astral Library is her first foray into magic realism. She and her husband now live in Maryland with their rescue dogs.

events.title: Virtual Author Talk: Kate Quinn
events.description: Step into a world where stories become real as we explore Kate Quinn’s imaginative new novel The Astral Library. The story follows Alexandria “Alix” Watson, who escapes her difficult past by losing herself in the Boston Public Library until she discovers a hidden doorway leading to a magical library where readers can enter the worlds they love. Guided by the sharp‑tongued Librarian, Alix soon finds herself pursued by a mysterious enemy and racing through the pages of classic literature, from Jane Austen to Sherlock Holmes to The Great Gatsby, as she fights to protect the Astral Library and the lives it shelters.This program is part of Santa Clara County Library District's celebration of Silicon Valley Reads. ---The Santa Clara County Library District is proud to present a free virtual author‑talk series featuring bestselling, award‑winning, and acclaimed writers from around the world, offering live Q&A sessions two to three times a month. Event links are sent about 24 hours in advance (or upon late registration), recordings are available for a limited time, and a full list of upcoming programs can be found here. ---For accessibility accommodations (ex. ASL), please fill out the online form at sccld.org/accessibility 7+days prior to the event. If you need assistance with the form, speak with a staff member at your local library, call (408) 540-3945, or email us at ask@lib.sccgov.org.

events.title: Out & About Reading Party
events.description: Join fellow book lovers from across Omaha for a quiet reading party with the Omaha Public Library! This nontraditional book club meets on the second Thursday of each month.This month we are at The Joslyn in the Fountain Court. This month we are at The Joslyn! Museum admission is free. Please review the museum guidelines before attending this event.There are no assigned readings—simply bring whatever you're currently reading, whether it's an ebook, audiobook, textbook, or comic book. It's truly "BYOBook." If you happen to forget your book or just pop in, OPL will have reading materials available for the duration of the program.Settle in for an hour of quiet, uninterrupted reading. Afterward, attendees have the option to socialize or not, as they prefer!Need sign language interpretation or other accessibility assistance for this event? Please email Nancy Novotny at NNovotny@omahalibrary.org to request accommodation. Requests must be made at least five business days before the activity or event.

location.name: The Joslyn
location.details: This month we are at The Joslyn in the Fountain Court! Museum admission is free. Please review the museum guidelines (https://joslyn.org/visit/museum-guidelines) before attending this event.

events.title: Inclusive Book Club with AAC (Online Event)
events.description: Hello Book Club Families, Book of the Week: A to Z Mysteries: The Canary CaperC is for Canary . . . Green Lawn has a pet problem! Dink’s neighbor can’t find her canary. Ruth Rose’s cat, Tiger, has also disappeared. Then the kids hear about two more missing critters. Is there a pet-napper in town? Dink, Josh, and Ruth Rose are on the case! About Our Book Club: Each week, an AAC user hosts our sessions, and a librarian reads our story. After each reading, we enjoy an activity or game connected to the book, celebrating representation, creativity, and the many wonderful ways people communicate. We celebrate all forms of communication—AAC, speech, gestures, and expressions—and follow a Floortime-inspired approach that centers on meeting readers where they are and building joyful shared experiences. When applicable, a visual schedule will be emailed 24 hours before each session to help our readers follow along. Special thanks to Ron Roy and Penguin Random House for allowing us to read A to Z Mysteries: The Canary Caper in our virtual book club.

book.title: A to Z Mysteries: The Canary Caper

events.title: Any Book Book Club
events.description: Love to read? Want to share your latest great read or find great recommendations? This book club is for you! New members are always welcome!

events.title: Book Clubs of EPL: Fahrenheit 451
events.description: Love reading? Love to talk about books you've read? Come join us for lively discussions on all types of fiction and non-fiction. We'll feature different titles and authors each month. Join us to share your impressions, thoughts and interpretations of a book we have all read. "Fahrenheit 451" by Ray BradburySYNOPSIS: Guy Montag is a fireman. His job is to destroy the most illegal of commodities, the printed book, along with the houses in which they are hidden. Montag never questions the destruction and ruin his actions produce, returning each day to his bland life and wife, Mildred, who spends all day with her television "family." But when he meets an eccentric young neighbor, Clarisse, who introduces him to a past where people didn't live in fear and to a present where one sees the world through the ideas in books instead of the mindless chatter of television, Montag begins to question everything he has ever known.

location.name: Riverbend
location.street: Riverbend Square, Rabbit Hill Road and Terwillegar Drive

events.title: Point Reyes and Tomales Bay: A People’s History in Print
events.description: Point Reyes is known for its organic farms and food, its natural beauty preserved in public parks, its creative communities, and its Instagram-ready attractions. If one looks back in history, the area surrounding Tomales Bay is also notable for the resilience of its Indigenous community, for the creation of the western dairy industry and its technological innovations, for the 1960s rock stars who lived in or frequented the area, and as a superb living example of America’s melting pot, where immigrants settled to find better lives—and succeeded.Dewey’s new book, Point Reyes And Tomales Bay, chronicles the land and people of Point Reyes, Tomales Bay, and the towns that were and still are very different from each other: Olema, Marshall, Point Reyes Station, and Inverness.California historian Dewey Livingston has been fascinated with Marin history since high school, spending the past 55 years exploring and researching his home, especially West Marin. For decades a National Park Service historian specializing in the rural West, and ten years as a MCFL map archivist, he spent the past ten years on a comprehensive history of the Point Reyes area.Sponsored by Friends of the Fairfax Library. ADA Accommodation Request | Solicitud de Adaptación ADA

events.title: *Virtual* Short Story Club
events.description: We meet over Zoom on the 2nd Thursday of each month 6:00-6:30 PM to discuss the selected short story. Links to the stories are provided on this event listing. Suggested age range for participants is 16 and up. Please register to receive a Zoom link 24 hours before the meeting, and again 1 hour before. Participants must enroll separately for each meeting.Our short stories for January through March 2026 are: January 8, 2026: The Secret Life of Walter Mitty by James ThurberFebruary 12, 2026: Speech Sounds by Octavia E. ButlerMarch 12, 2026: A Family Supper by Kazuo Ishiguro Suggestions for short stories for future meetings are encouraged! (Send suggestions to Thomas.Hewitt@sjlibrary.org) ADA Accommodation Requests

events.title: Cookbook Book Club
events.description: Do you love food and cooking? Join us for the Cookbook Book Club, where each month we explore a new cookbook, try out recipes, and share our experiences. Featured cookbook will be available for checkout at the meeting. Then, on the 2nd Thursday of the month, we'll meet, share pictures, stories and reviews of the dishes you cooked!Visit our Cookbook Book Club Info Hub to find out more! No registration is required at this time. This book club is for adults ages 18+.

events.title: Pageturners: South of the Border, West of the Sun by Haruki Murakami
events.description: Palo Alto Pageturners meets on the second Thursday of the month in the Embarcadero Room. At the end of each year, we suggest and vote on books to read and sometimes invite local authors to discuss their books. You don't have to register, but you will receive a reminder email if you register. Here's our reading list for 2026: My Friends by Fredrik Bachman - JanuaryThe Wager: A Tale of a Shipwreck, Mutiny and Murder by David Grann - FebruarySouth of the Border, West of the Sun by Haruki Murakami - MarchTrespassers at the Golden Gate: A True Account of Love, Murder, and Madness in Gilded-Age San Francisco by Gary Krist - AprilThe Best We Could Do by Thi Bui - MayThe Wedding People by Alison Espach - JuneUnlikely Animals: A Novel by Annie Hartnett - JulySay Nothing: A True Story of Murder and Memory in Northern Ireland by Patrick Radden Keefe - AugustThe Frozen River by Ariel Lawhon - SeptemberWe'll Prescribe You a Cat by Syou Ishida - OctoberWhat We Can Know by Ian McEwan - NovemberThe Amazing Adventures of Kavalier & Clay by Michael Chabon - December Sign up for the library newsletter and never miss another program!

events.title: Graphic Novel Book Club: Women's History Month
events.description: Monthly book discussion on a graphic novel selected by the group! This program is for readers age 16 and up. 2025-2026 titles: September 11: Understanding Comics by Scott McCloud (1994), 224 pagesOctober 9: Artificial: A Love Story by Amy Kurzweil (2023), 368 pagesNovember 13: The Road by Cormac McCarthy (2024), 160 pagesDecember 11: The House by Paco Roca (2019), 134 pagesJanuary 8: In: A Graphic Novel by Will McPhail (2021), 272 pagesFebruary 12: Special presentations by book club members who are authors: Mimi & Soni Discover Dussehra Legends by Devika Joglekar (2019), Kye in the Valley of Gold by Kyle Hurlbut (2024), Smiling Through the Mask by Daniele Archambault (2022), as well as artist Deborah J. Miller who will be sharing her current project.March 12: Feeding Ghosts by Tessa Hulls (2024), 400 pagesApril 9: Yellow Cab by Benoit Cohen (2022), 168 pagesMay 14: 40 Men and 12 Rifles: Indochina 1954 by Marcelino Truong (2023), 296 pagesTitles can be borrowed from the Palo Alto City Library and through our Link+ system - click on the links above or search in our catalog for more information. Meetings are held in person in the Midtown Room at Mitchell Park Library and facilitated by Danièle Archambault. The GNBC has been meeting since 2015! Danièle Archambault, Ph.D. (Linguistics), is a researcher, author, and educator who is interested in comics as a way to document a society's cultural and linguistic landscape. Originally from Montreal, Quebec, she now lives in Palo Alto, where she is an artist in residence at the Cubberley Artist Studio Program, a program of the City of Palo Alto. In the past few years, she has published several full-color comic books, graphic novels, and electronic books. Ms. Archambault is a regular guest speaker on documenting culture and dialects through comics at various educational and cultural institutions. She teaches Visual Storytelling at the Palo Alto Art Center, and at other educational venues. http://danielebd.com/

events.title: Finding Marian Abel at Los Altos  Library
events.description: Join longtime library commissioner Pierre Bedard and LAHS' Gustav Herhne for a special book club celebrating Marian Abel’s History of the Los Altos Library (1914-1964). The history, written in 1972, explores the library’s first 50 years. Register and get a PDF of her work so you can prepare for the book club. Marian Abel loved Los Altos. Let's celebrate our history and look forward to the next fifty years!For accessibility accommodations (ex. ASL), please fill out the online form at sccld.org/accessibility 7+days prior to the event. If you need assistance with the form, speak with a staff member at your local library, call (408) 540-3945, or email us at ask@lib.sccgov.org.

events.title: Little Makers Club (Ages 0-5): Transportation
events.description: This themed, literacy-based drop in program is chock full of activities to help prepare your child for school and beyond. We'll work on motor skills, literacy and counting all while playing in an enriching environment that allows for socialization and for each child to choose their own activity (matching their energy level). Crafts and toddler-friendly snacks will be provided, along with a weekly take-home goody bag to continue learning at home. Manage your event registration through "My Events" when signed in to a library account. DISCOVER MORE Running of out books to read? Ask a librarian for even more personalized recommendations!Visit the Kids Page to discover additional recommendations and resources.

events.title: Intermediate ESL Book Club - Skylark
events.description: Our intermediate ESL Book Club will read Sarah, Plain and Tall by Patricia MacLachlan. This book club is best for intermediate English learners. Students will read at home each week. Then we will meet as a group once a week to talk about the story, learn new vocabulary, and practice conversation. Book club will be led by Elaine Hilbelink. Meeting dates: February 27; March 6, 13, 20, 27; April 3 Meeting time: Fridays 10am - 11am Where: Literacy Table Registration is open now! Book club is limited to 10 participants. Books will be provided for registered participants to keep. Please consider your schedule and do not register if you will miss more than one meeting. Skylark description:The second book in the series that began with the Newbery Medal–winning Sarah, Plain and Tall by Patricia MacLachlan. Sarah came to the prairie from Maine to marry Papa. But that summer, a drought turned the land dry and brown. Fires swept across the fields and coyotes came to the well in search of water. So Sarah took Anna and Caleb back east, where they would be safe. Papa stayed behind. He would not leave his land. Maine was beautiful, but Anna missed home, and Papa. And as the weeks went by, she began to wonder what would happen if the rains never came. Would she and Caleb and Sarah and Papa ever be a family again?

events.title: Graphic Novel Book Club: Night Chef
events.description: Join other readers to discuss a different graphic novel each month. Ages 10-14. Registration required. --- This month we're reading Night Chef by Mika Song. "Ratatouille meets the magic of Studio Ghibli as a lonely raccoon who secretly lives inside a fine French restaurant and yearns to be a chef must venture into the woods for the first time to help a baby crow find its home. The Night Chef has never had a family— only a dream. She's spent years living inside the walls of a human restaurant, honing her cooking skills. She knows she can fry an omelette with the best of them— but she also knows that humans will never accept her. And so she keeps to herself, hidden and alone. Then, one evening, when Night Chef cracks an egg open for her dinner, a baby crow named Ichi falls out! Despite being reluctant to leave her home, Night Chef steps into the wilds in order to reunite Ichi with his family. And along the journey, she might just find a family to call her own, too."

events.title: Teen Advisory Board @ Main TeenZone
events.description: Interested in creating your own teen programs or events? Got a club you've always wanted to start or a skill you'd love to share? Drop in to our monthly Teen Advisory Board (TAB) meetings on the second *Friday* of the month at the Main Library TeenZone to learn more about what's possible at TAB and start collaborating with other teens. Snacks provided!TAB is a youth-led, librarian-supported volunteer group for youth in 7th—12th grades who are excited to take an active role in shaping what we offer to teens at the Main TeenZone. As a TAB member, you get the opportunity to: Make real your ideas for the TeenZone as a place for teens, by teens! Develop real-world skills and experience that you can use in job and college applications Fulfill your community service hour requirements Enjoy food, fun, and friendship at our monthly meet-ups Fill out a volunteer application here. events.title: Bite Sized Book Club- The Factory Witches of Lowell
events.description: Think you're too busy for a book club? Think again! Schlafly's "Bite-Sized Books" features diverse selections under 250 pages - a perfect fit for busy students, parents and professionals. Whether you're looking to try new genres, sample a different perspective or fit in a quick read during your kiddo's nap time, this club has you covered. Join us for our Saturday one-hour discussions every month. And if our current theme isn't for you, don't fret - check back in July for our next topic!This unit's focus is "Fantastical History", and March's selection is "The Factory Witches of Lowell" by C.S. Malerich (128 pages). This read has elements of fantasy and historical fiction, with LGBTQIA+ characters. Description - "Faced with abominable working conditions, unsympathetic owners, and hard-hearted managers, the mill girls of Lowell have had enough. They're going on strike, and they have a secret weapon on their side: a little witchcraft to ensure that no one leaves the picket line."

events.title: Castro Valley Reads Discussion Group
events.description: Join us for a discussion of the book selection for Castro Valley Reads! Our selection for 2026 is Advice for Future Corpses* (And those who love them) by Sallie Tisdale. From the sublime (the faint sound of Mozart as you take your last breath) to the ridiculous (lessons on how to close the sagging jaw of a corpse), Tisdale leads us through the peaks and troughs of death with a calm, wise, and humorous hand. Advice for Future Corpses is more than a how-to manual or a spiritual bible: it is a graceful compilation of honest and intimate anecdotes based on the deaths Tisdale has witnessed in her work and life, as well as stories from cultures, traditions, and literature around the world. Free copies of the book are available while supplies last. The free copies will be distributed beginning Sunday, February 1, at 2 pm at the CV Reads Kick-Off Event. The book is also available in the Library collection. Advice for Future Corpses* An ASL (American Sign Language) interpreter or closed captioning can be provided for this program if requested at least seven (7) days in advance. For assistance, please contact your library or accessibility@aclibrary.org.

events.title: Castro Valley Reads Discussion Group
events.description: Join us for a discussion of the book selection for Castro Valley Reads! Our selection for 2026 is Advice for Future Corpses* (And those who love them) by Sallie Tisdale. From the sublime (the faint sound of Mozart as you take your last breath) to the ridiculous (lessons on how to close the sagging jaw of a corpse), Tisdale leads us through the peaks and troughs of death with a calm, wise, and humorous hand. Advice for Future Corpses is more than a how-to manual or a spiritual bible: it is a graceful compilation of honest and intimate anecdotes based on the deaths Tisdale has witnessed in her work and life, as well as stories from cultures, traditions, and literature around the world. Free copies of the book are available while supplies last. The free copies will be distributed beginning Sunday, February 1, at 2 pm at the CV Reads Kick-Off Event. The book is also available in the Library collection. Advice for Future Corpses* An ASL (American Sign Language) interpreter or closed captioning can be provided for this program if requested at least seven (7) days in advance. For assistance, please contact your library or accessibility@aclibrary.org.

events.title: Book Clubs of EPL: Born A Crime
events.description: Love reading? Love to talk about books you've read? Join our book club for spirited discussions on a wide range of fiction and non-fiction. Each month we'll tackle a new title. Whether you loved it, loathed it, or left it unfinished, we want to hear your take. Come share your impressions and connect with fellow readers! This week we will be reading Born A Crime by Trevor Noah. "One of the comedy world's fastest-rising stars tells his wild coming of age story during the twilight of apartheid in South Africa and the tumultuous days of freedom that followed. Noah provides something deeper than traditional memorists: powerfully funny observations about how farcical political and social systems play out in our lives. Trevor Noah is the host of The Daily Show with Trevor Noah, where he gleefully provides America with its nightly dose of serrated satire. He is a light-footed but cutting observer of the relentless absurdities of politics, nationalism and race--and in particular the craziness of his own young life, which he's lived at the intersections of culture and history. In his first book, Noah tells his coming of age story with his larger-than-life mother during the last gasps of apartheid-era South Africa and the turbulent years that followed. Noah was born illegal--the son of a white, Dutch father and a black Xhosa mother, who had to pretend to be his nanny or his father's servant in the brief moments when the family came together. His brilliantly eccentric mother loomed over his life--a comically zealous Christian (they went to church six days a week and three times on Sunday), a savvy hustler who kept food on their table during rough times, and an aggressively involved, if often seriously misguided, parent who set Noah on his bumpy path to stardom. The stories Noah tells are sometimes dark, occasionally bizarre, frequently tender, and always hilarious--whether he's subsisting on caterpillars during months of extreme poverty or making comically pitiful attempts at teenage romance in a color-obsessed world; whether's he's being thrown into jail as the hapless fall guy for a crime he didn't commit or being thrown by his mother from a speeding car driven by murderous gangsters."

events.title: 星期一下午:西游记 (读书会)
events.description: A book club dedicated to "Journey to the West," the classic Chinese fiction. This club is designed for children who are fans of the story and is conducted entirely in Mandarin Chinese. The event is organized by dedicated teen volunteers from Lynbrook High School.小朋友们，你们听说过《西游记》吗？ 这是中国最有名的神话故事之一，讲述了一段惊险又有趣的旅程。在这个故事里，有聪明勇敢的孙悟空、善良慈悲的唐僧、憨厚搞笑的猪八戒，还有忠诚可靠的沙和尚。他们一路上经历了许多危险和考验，但靠着智慧和团结，成功完成了任务。这次旅程不仅是他们追寻经书的故事，更是一场关于勇气、坚持和成长的冒险！更多有关 美猴王系列丛书. 免费的亲子中文活動. 座位数量有限. 门票将在故事时间开始前 30 分钟在询问处领取。 圖書館中文资源: 大人最新中文书, 中文電子書, 非小說類電子書 (Overdrive) 有歡迎大家一起來借閱電子書. Overdirve平台: 小朋友的中文電子書, 大朋友的中文電子小說, 大朋友的非小說類的電子書籍. Hoopla平台: 中文有聲書籍 美国残疾人法案(ADA)申请提供协助 5/25/2026

events.title: Book Clubs of EPL: Tom Lake
events.description: Love reading? Love to talk about books you've read? Come join us for lively discussions on all types of fiction and non-fiction. We'll feature different titles and authors each month. Come and share your impressions, thoughts and interpretations of a book we have all read. This week we will be reading Tom Lake by Ann Patchett.In the spring of 2020, Lara's three daughters return to the family's orchard in Northern Michigan. While picking cherries, they beg their mother to tell them the story of Peter Duke, a famous actor with whom she shared both a stage and a romance years before at a theater company called Tom Lake. As Lara recalls the past, her daughters examine their own lives and relationship with their mother, and are forced to reconsider the world and everything they thought they knew.

events.title: Manchester Book Group
events.description: Pick up the next book club selection at the Manchester library service desk following the previous month's meeting on the 3rd Monday of the month. **NOTE Meetings in January and February each year are held on the FOURTH Monday of the month due to the Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Day and President's Day holidays This month we are discussing:What An Owl Knows by Jennifer Ackerman From the Publisher: From the author of The Genius of Birds and The Bird Way, a brilliant scientific investigation into owls—the most elusive of birds—and why they exert such a hold on human imaginationWith their forward gaze and quiet flight, owls are often a symbol of wisdom, knowledge, and foresight. But what does an owl really know? And what do we really know about owls? Some two hundred sixty species of owls exist today, and they reside on every continent except Antarctica, but they are far more difficult to find and study than other birds because they are cryptic, camouflaged, and mostly active at night. Though human fascination with owls goes back centuries, scientists have only recently begun to understand the complex nature of these extraordinary birds.

The Central Park StoryWalk® begins near the Alcosta parking lot to the right of the playground, ending at the Community Center’s rear fountain. The StoryWalk Project was created by Anne Ferguson of Montpelier, VT and developed in collaboration with the Kellogg-Hubbard Library. StoryWalk is a registered service mark owned by Ms. Ferguson.

events.title: Flights of Fantasy: The Will of the Many - Part 1
events.description: Enjoy reading fantasy? Each month, we'll discuss an exciting novel from the fantasy and sci-fi genres. —- Join Krista M. at Coffee Hub in Beavercreek to discuss this month's book The Will of the Many, a novel by James Islington. Part 1 - Please read chapters I-XXXVI. Stop on page 349 (paperback). A preview:"Vis, the adopted son of Magnus Quintus Ulcisor, a prominent senator within the Hierarchy, is trained to enter the famed Catenan Academy to help Ulciscor learn what the hidden agenda is of the remote island academy. Secretly, he also wants Vis to discover what happed to his brother who died at the academy. He is sure the current Principalis of the academy, Quintus Veridius Julii, a political rival, knows much more than he's revealing. The Academy's vigorous syllabus is a challenge Vis is ably suited to meet, but it is the training in the use of Will, a practice that Vis finds abhorrent, that he must learn in order to excel at the Academy. Will, a concept that encompasses their energy, drive, focus, initiative, ambition, and vitality, can be voluntarily "ceded" to someone else. A single recipient can accept ceded Will from multiple people, growing in power towards superhuman levels. Within the hierarchy your level of Will, or legal rank, determines how you live or die. And there are those who are determined to destroy this hierarchal system, as well as those in the Academy who use it to gain dominance in internationally bestselling author James Islington's wonderfully crafted new epic fantasy series"--
